Title: 1863 December 11COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Cousin Clementine
Creator: Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; HainesCOMMA Mary RhoadsCOMMA 1819-1905; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; HainesCOMMA ReubenCOMMA 1851-1920; StokesCOMMA Tom (Thomas Pym Cope)COMMA 1843-1918; WarnerCOMMA YardleyCOMMA 1815?-1885;
Subject: Education; Youth in church work; Outdoor recreation; Sports; Community life
Transcript:
Awbury Dec. 11th 1863

Here’s a nice stormy 6th day afternoon at lastCOMMA My dear Cousin ClementineCOMMA in which I can find a little time to write to theeCOMMA I expect thee thinks I am very naughty indeed not to have found a little time beforeCOMMA but if I had thee here I could so completly convince thee in half an hourCOMMA that thee would entirely agree with meCOMMA that it is a moral impossibility ever to get any time to write letters. We have learned a great many things AngelicaCOMMA since last I had the pleasure of conversing with theeCOMMA (I wonder how many months it has been) Yardley as well as Mary Haines has become ourinstructorCOMMA other-wise intelligently he is teaching us to rideCOMMA thee don’t know what fun it isCOMMA we have splendid timesCOMMA Yardley & one of his daughters always goesCOMMA & sometimes Tom or ReubenCOMMA & Cousin LillieCOMMA Jammy or CasperCOMMA & very rarely Tom StokesCOMMA however I believe Yardly don’t approve of him as Rachel & he behaved badly the other afternoon riding too far ahead for Yardley’s notionsCOMMA so he came posting over in the evening & held a private conversation on the piazza with fatherCOMMA to R’s extreme disgust & indignation. I suppose thee has heard of our charities over at the meeting houseCOMMA we have got up some contraband meetings for the benefitof the “Young Friends Association” they have a man to cut out the thingsCOMMA & then they are sent round to the various meetings to be made up. We have a branch concern here every 3rd day evening & have a great deal of funCOMMA especialy after Yardley & his daughters leaveCOMMA we get tired of our work by that timeCOMMA & have a little music “both vocal & instrumental”.
But the last & greatest funCOMMA that we have nowCOMMA is skattingCOMMA Oh! Cousin ClemCOMMA I do wish thee would come overCOMMA yesterday afternoon was grandCOMMA I haven’t enjoyed any thing so much for agesCOMMA the ice was delightfully smoothCOMMA & my skates elegantly sharpCOMMA & they glided over so swiftlyCOMMA as to give metwo or three pretty hard tumbles. Some of the gentlemen rolled splendidlyCOMMA the Sun in particular he was one of the best skaters on the dam. Compositions are as horrid as everCOMMA imagin my having to write one last night in addition to all my other lessons after I got homeCOMMA with my head full of every thing else; I missed thy help very muchCOMMA does thee remember how thee used to give me ideasCOMMA last winter. O! Cousin Clem I wish thee would come back again. We had the nicest walk last 1st day afternoon that ever wasCOMMA we went all round by Harpers & Butlers dams thee knowsCOMMA a whole party of us Stokes & Awbury folks in addition toMiss A.C. SmithCOMMA I said we had a delightful walkCOMMA & so we had as far as the walk wentCOMMA but I believe I wasn’t in a very good mood to enjoyCOMMA however I am not going to tell thee about my mopy fitsCOMMA I never have them nowCOMMA ever since I had that talk with thee at Newport I determined to have nothing more to do with them; & I was dreadfully provoked at myself for indulging last first-day afternoonCOMMA I beleive a conversation I had in the morning rather effected my spirits. But how foolish I am! thee’ll think I haven’t improved a bit if I go on rattling about myself this way. But CousinClementine thee will have to come over here right-soonCOMMA or I shall begin to think we are never to see thee again.
I was very much obliged for thy photographCOMMA though I must say I can’t flatter thee on it thee way Uncle Harry didCOMMA whats thee think he said about it? he was looking over my albumCOMMA & when he came to it he said to me “thats a fancy piece aint it”. I laughed & told him who it wasCOMMA & he said “it was so pretty it ought to be put in the stores in Chestnut St.” wasn’t that complementary now? But I don’t think it is near pretty enough to be put in Chestnut St. nor do I think it at all does thee justiceCOMMA & I hope thee won’tforget thee has promised me one of those really pretty ones. But now I geuss thee is beginning to be quite tired of my nonsense so I will close; hoping thee will answer this very soon in person

ever thy affec. little Lily

Title: 1865 November 18COMMA Locust ShadeCOMMA to Ruthanna Cope
Creator: Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; ReeveCOMMA Julia K.; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?
Unidentified People: Cousin Eliza; George B. Wood; Mary Ann Morris; Lizzie[Susan’s daughter]; John andSallie Hilles;
Subject: Family;  Health; Education;
Transcript:
Locust Shade 11.18.1865

My Dear Annie

That thy very interesting letter has thus long remained unanswered has been that I have not very often thought of theeCOMMA as I trust thee knowst- and I was much disappointed to find that I had gone to Germantown a week too soon to see thee. This to be sure I had but a few hours to stay thereCOMMA still I had hoped to spend part of them with thee.- I hope dear Annie thee is better for thy sojourn at Newport. For I know the return home without thy father’s welcome must have been very painful.- even with all the love & kindness of thy brothers &
sisters and with the strong consolation thee has of believing that thy dear parents are forever “where adieus and farewells are a sound unknown”.- May we realize more & more the infinite importance of eternal things.- For myself I seem to glide on day after day occupied with a round of dutiesCOMMA but in a kind of lethargy in regard to spiritual things Certainly without that earnest striving which is commanded & which we may believe is essential to Christian progress- But confession of our faults avails little without amendment & I should not burden the with mine.
We have parted with our Lizzie to go to Select school. She boards with John and Sallie Hilles who very kindly offered to take her- & so far likes her school very much better
than any she ever attended before. I loved that school very much & whenever I think of itCOMMA always seeCOMMA in my minds eyeCOMMA- thee & Julia & Clemmy coming in - & going to the cloak room.-
We miss Lizzie exceedingly & I am ready to wonder how we shall do without her for six months.- She is to come home after every monthly examination & I long for the time to arrive.-
Has Clemmy been much with thee lately? I have scarcely heard of her since her return from Baltimore or of Julia for a long time- I saw some of George’s pictures favorably noted in an “art criticism” the other dayCOMMA at least I supposed they were his. George B. Wood is his nameCOMMA isnt it?
How sad it is that Mary Ann Morris
continued so poorly- tho indeed it is not to be wondered at. Mary wrote me a few days ago- that she was still much afflicted with sleeplessness - & was very nervous. The former must be most distressing & very [wearing] upon the constitution.- I hope cousin Eliza will be better for living in Germantown as the trips out there have done her so much good. It is to be hoped their walls will not tumble down before they get moved tho [-----] does not think it would be son fine & exciting. – I think their house will be a good way from you will it not? I am hoping dear Annie to spend a few days with thee before a very great while- tho I cannot now see when it will be – probably not for some weeks.- Tho I do want exceedingly to see thee & as I said before fully expected to before this. Please write to me when thee feels like it.- Father mother have gone out to teaor would said their love- Mine please to thy sister Lizzie & a large share for thy self from they truly attached
Susie-

Title: 1857 June 17COMMA New YorkCOMMA to Anne
Creator: Martha Leeds:  1810?-1888
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Rachel ReeveCOMMA 1794-1863; PleasantsCOMMA Laura; ReeveCOMMA Julia K.; SmileyCOMMA Eliza; KingCOMMA John AlsopCOMMA 1788-1867; DowningCOMMA JacobCOMMA 1756-1823; DowningCOMMA Joseph R.COMMA 1765-1855; LeggettCOMMA Frances VauxCOMMA 1797?-1876; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; WoodCOMMA FernandoCOMMA 1812-1881; SmileyCOMMA Albert K. (Albert Keith)COMMA 1828-1912; RobinsonCOMMA SolonCOMMA 1803-1880; LeggettCOMMA Thomas HaightCOMMA 1787-1867; LeedsCOMMA BarclayCOMMA 1834-1918; LeedsCOMMA Lewis W. (Lewis Walker) ca. 1827-1896; LeggettCOMMA HannahCOMMA 1833-1910
Unidentified People: WilliamCOMMA RebeccaCOMMA FatherCOMMA AmeliaCOMMA HannahCOMMA NealieCOMMA Martha(their cook)COMMA General (Charles W.) SandfordCOMMA J. L. Woodward and wife
Subject: Railroad travel;  Women domestics; Self-careCOMMA Health; Traditional medicine; Health; Riots; Death; Poverty; Police;
Geographic Subjects: New York (N.Y.); Perth Amboy (N.J.); Trenton (N.J.); New Orleans (La.); Chicago (Ill.); Mississippi River; Awbury (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.)
Notes:
Author mentions Stewart’sCOMMA one of the first department storesCOMMA located at 280 BroadwayCOMMA New York (N.Y.). Known as the "Marble Palace" for its stone pillarsCOMMA this new concept helped make shopping fashionable for wealthy women.

Fernando Wood served nine intermittent terms in CongressCOMMA beginning in 1841COMMA and three terms as Mayor of New York City. The riots that Martha writes about in this letter stem from rival gubernatorial and mayoral appointments to replace the New York City Street Commissioner. (For an in-depth look at this crisisCOMMA see Jerome MushkatCOMMA Ch. 5COMMA “The Political MayorCOMMA” in Fernando Wood: A Political Biography (KentCOMMA OH: Kent State University PressCOMMA 1990)).

Solon Robinson's "Hot Corn” vignettes of city life among the impoverished and immigrant communities were later collected in a bookCOMMA entitled “Hot Corn StoriesCOMMA” which must have been known to Martha and to Anne either in serial or book form.

The “little Katy” mentioned in the letter may not refer to a family member but rather to the title character of one of Robinson’s stories. HoweverCOMMA hsc0022 mentions a girl named Katy staying with the Leeds family.

Dictionary defines collodion as “a solution of gun-cotton in etherCOMMA forming a colourles gummy liquidCOMMA which dries rapidly in the airCOMMA owing to evaporation of the ether.” Collodion was used in photography to cover glass plates as well as in medicine to cover wounds.

Tarleton muslin is a stiffCOMMA lightweightCOMMA finely woven cotton fabric.
Transcript:
New York 6 mo 17th 1857 —

My dear AnneCOMMA

Laura just brought me up thy letter to read I had been lying down since dinner and after our journey down to meeting felt like resting – I felt almost afraid to go down in the neighbourhood of the City Hall where we went to Stewart’s to get some tarleton muslin to see if we could not fold it so as to cover the cracks of William’s big looking glass – it will look better and I expect Laura will have it hung in the spare roomCOMMA where thee can look at thyself from head to foot when thee comes on – felt glad that Rebecca happened to be out ready to take thy place in waiting on thy mother – forgot to say why I was afraid to go in the neighbourhood of the City Hall suppose the papers have informed you of the riot between the police appointed by the Mayor and those under the Govenor there was a great time yesterday but I believeit is all quiet at present. I suppose they have a queer sort of a mayor here and I felt a hope that after this outbreak that a new order of things may be instituted and that we shall have the Streets cleaned – I want thee to tell Anna that I feel so much obliged to her for telling me of the remedy for dyspepsia I have been so much better since I commenced taking it – I hope that I shall be able soon to partake with others of what is put on the table. I am so fond of clamsCOMMA and as they are so nice here at New York and we have them frequentlyCOMMA I feel it quite a deprivation – Am able to eat strawberries. We had them in abundance at Father’s where we went 7th day evening sisters Amelia & Hannah were there and several cousins went with us besides Barclay and the country was so beautiful and so sweet from the clover fields that it did seem to me quite a treat – we left second day morning in the cars for New York – Came in the accommodation trainby the way of Amboy – it was new to me and I enjoyed it much more than the other route by Trenton – Last evening Solon Robinson one who writes for the "Tribune"* [*Is one of the editors I am told] spent the evening with us he is a near neighbour – he wrote the "hot Corn" stories for the Tribune and lately "a day in the country" which appeared in that paper – a singular looking man his age is 54 – wears a beard probably 6 inches long and perfectly whiteCOMMA his hair also long and white – he told us he had travelled with one pair of horses from New Orleans to Chicago and from thence to New York $5000 miles and the horses just ready to run away the day after he got home – he described his attack of Cholera on the Missisippi and of the enormous dose of opiumCOMMA Quinine &c which they gave him of the former quite an ounce he thought – I told him of [Gimre’s] himaepathic potion!– He also mentioned an illness of the smallpox and said he had it as badly as it was possible – upon my remarking that he was not pitted with it he told me howhe prevented it by covering the pustules immediately upon breaking with collodion – Some of the pustules were as large as a hickory nutCOMMA others smaller – but not a place on his whole person where he could have put a quarter of a dollar down with out touching some – we were entertained with his conversation but did not admire him any of us – quite eccentric – I did not know he wrote the "hot corn stories" untill he left – he was down on the beggars said it was sinful to give indiscriminately seemed to think it was no use to give to them that they could not be made to help themselves – that they might as well die one time as another which quite shocked us to hear him say – he has distributed about $12000 and I suppose has become totally discouraged in the prospect of doing any good – He thinks almost all are petty thieves – Laura has had 4 articles taken that she had put out with ashes in – knows not what to do – they will take even a barrel and break up for firewood – Thos Leggett had their door mat stolen as well as Woodwards’ and the next door the other side – We have concluded to keep ours in the hall as it has escaped hithertoEvery few minutes there is a knock at the basement door – Robinson says "let them knock and take no notice –" does it not seem queer that a man that could write so feelingly about the poor should say so? – but indeed we know not what to do scarcely and to feel that we do right – I never saw such a place – One evening Thos Leggett was in here about dark we were all in the basement and a poor little thin creature like Katy came to ask for something – Tom thought he would go with her and see her home which he did and after he returned he could not speak for tears – the scene of utter destitution affected him so much – The father could not work had the ague and he thought that they looked as if they had all become thin through want of food – she had been coming here almost daily for food since – This morning we saw a group of little ones the largest girl carrying a box which looked to be an ash box and Laura thought looking back apprehen-sively. We thought they had stolen it. Robinson may feel more than he pretends to about them – We heard he wrote for a long time "City Items" for the Tribune and they almost all contained some interesting incidents respecting the poor – he informed us he possessed remarkably descriptive powers that nothing he saw escaped his notice &c. We concluded he must be a genius and consequently eccentric – he told us he had an adopted daughter that always shaves him – cuts his hair makes all his clothes with the assistance of a sewing machine as well as all her own sewing and sometimes her shoes – William thinks it likely she is one perhaps that he has rescued –
We found Nealie here after we returned from meeting we are all invited up there Seventh day (Barclay and ourselves)– we expect to go if they get a cook– A few days ago an old servant of theirs dropped down dead whilst at work in the kitchen which was a great shock to them they had to have a coroners inquest – Laura says perhaps we will go and take Martha tocook whilst we stay – Laura has engaged the nicest little girl to run errands do chamber work &c – she does work admirably sews beautifully – irons &c they think she will suit them better than a larger girl – she is a trim little thing with beautiful hair which she has always in nice order – got a very good character of her – the gentleman she lived with (a lawyer) wrote her character – that she was the best child he had ever known in her capacity – they parted with her in consequence of going out West –
I do not remember whether I told you about the Cornell’s friends of Hannah Leggett who board with them the elder (Eliza) has been a teacher in one of the best schools in the city received a salary of $600 – she is going to be married in about three weeks to Albert Smiley. she is a sweet looking girl as well as a younger sister with whom Barclay has become well acquainted – JL Woodward is very much interested in them – he likes young company – when Laura told his wife that she thought perhaps some of hercousins would come home with us – she said "Mr Woodward will be delighted" We are to take tea there this evening – Leggetts & ourselves –
5th day. We heard that Mayor Wood was obliged to accept warrants from the Metropolitan police who accompanied by Gen Sandford presented them to him—he is under arrest – I feel anxious to hear what has transpired to day – Lewis & William and every New Yorker I expect are so much interested – Wood has behaved so badly – It was thought that Sandford had acted with great circumspection and he was the hero of the day – but if the Mayor had not submittedCOMMA he told him that the law would be enforced at the point of the bayonet – happily yesterday passed without bloodshed – The mayor with his 800 policemen were in the City Hall = It was suggested that they might be starved into submission by preventing egress –
Well Anne dear I hope thy foot will not trouble thee long it was the best thing to take care in time of a sprained ancle – such a useful little body as thee has become cannot be spared very well – Laura joins me in love to all at Awbury – will write soon to thee herself as I have more time on my hands I have taken the pen this time and shall be glad
to have a reply – I am looking for an answer to my letter from Julia soon we do enjoy getting letters so far away from all of you –Must now say farewell as my sheet is filled and remain as ever thy very affectionate Aunt Martha

Title: 1878 July 6COMMA NewportCOMMA to Clemmy
Creator: Emily Rose
Identified People: StevensCOMMA Martha Bayard;
Unidentified People: Emily RoseCOMMA author. Also unidentified: Aunt of Emily Rose;   cousin of Emily Rose; gentleman who founded the New York   College of Physiatry and Surgery; his wife; Mrs. HighbeeCOMMA   her sister; D. Lathrop of Montrose; Miss Walker; Dr. and   Mrs. Parker; Mary PowellCOMMA and Mrs. Yoffee
Subject: Voyages and Travels;  Weddings; Newport (R.I.)--Description   and Voyages and Travels; Inheritance and succession; Rental housing;
Geographic Subjects: Montrose (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.); Newport (R.I.); Europe; New York (N.Y.)
Notes:
No postal information appears on the letter; the supplementary index to the finding aid for the collection lists Connymeade as the destination.

“The” Avenue that Emily refers to in the letter is likely Bellevue AvenueCOMMA one of the main thoroughfares of Newport. From Newport and How to See It (Newport: Davis & PitmanCOMMA 1869). A map of Newport and several of the buildings mentioned in the letterCOMMA including the building standing on the corner of Bellevue and BerkleyCOMMA from which Emily wrote this letterCOMMA may be found on p. 217 of John Sterngrass’ First Resorts.
Transcript:
NewportCOMMA JulyCOMMA 6thCOMMA 1878

Dearest ClemmyCOMMA
I wonder where your darling little ladyship is at this moment? I wish it was here amid all the greenness & breezes of NewportCOMMA Ocean AirsCOMMA & perhaps you are or are Coming as I know you do sometimes. For me – You know I was with my dear Aunt last winter & now that she has taken this fine house I am with her Still – & certainly it is the perfection of living. My Aunt has taken the whole house it is neat & handsome & an excellent table – $1.000 per month. when we are at breakfast our rooms are arranged.the owners live in some mysterious addition to the house but we never see or hear anything of the machinery
Aunt has her maid & my cousin –(by the way Clemmy since I cant now have you for a "Sister" how would "Cousin"– suit thee? he is very good & wealthy & well born &c?) has his man & horses – There are lovely trees & fields all round – We are on "the Avenue" next the Ocean HouseCOMMA & in front is the large place of a Cousin – the lady is an only child & her father lately died leaving 7. millions! So the world is shared! They spent the evening here last night – looking as joyous as tho they had 7 milns but not at all as tho’ a new tombstone stood for them in a graveyardCOMMA so the world goes! But oh! give me less. & a heart aching to deaths very door for the filled grave.– however long ago = Who would take joy if it must be coupled with heartlessness? Thank God for real griefs whatever He sends. Do they not "all work together for good"COMMA & then there are so many bright delicious joys! Thank God indeed for them! The world is so full of sunshine! If the railroad is finished into our beautiful town – Aunt & my Cousin will visit meCOMMA & also – "whether or no" A Cousin of mine who is here now with us – wife of the late "President of the New York College of [Physiciary] & Surgeons" & sister of a very lovely lady a Mrs Highbee who boarded awhile at Mr D. Lathrops in Montrose in 1867COMMA while I was in Europe. She seems quite delighted with the prospect – & now I want you to come also & visit me the latter part of August & SeptemberI told Aunt she must let me go home then & dear Clemmy I do want your dear sensible loving heart – & I think I could make it pleasant to you – I will be very goodCOMMA & let you go to Miss Walkers & your other friends & if your parents & sisters or brothers are up we will entertain them – Give them a handsome party as I gave those dear Dr & Mrs Parker last fall. Come! My Cousin Mrs Edwin A StevensCOMMA whose husband left some 60 or 70 millions has invited me – to visit her but I would rather have you as my guest – So now write me immediately & tell me you are coming to me. Give the kindest of all kind remembrances to your parents Time or distance never weaken my loving memories – I went on to Phil in Apr to Miss Mary Powell’s wedding & was so sorry not to be able to get out to see you all but I hadso many friends who claimed me for the short time my friends in N.Y. would spare me. Hoping to hear soon from you & sending love to each of your family Believe me as ever most affectionately yr friend

Emily RoseCOMMA

Care of Mrs [Goffee]
Cor Berkely & Bellevue Aves
NewportCOMMA R.I.

Title: 1865 May 27COMMA Locust ShadeCOMMA to Annie
Creator: Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; JohnsonCOMMA AndrewCOMMA 1808-1875; SmithCOMMA Daniel B.COMMA 1792-1883; ThomasCOMMA Deborah C. 1817-1889;
Unidentified People: Jeff; Bettie; Uncle John & Aunt R. Smith;cos Lizzie; Richard Howland; Lilly and Philip;
Subject: Letter writing;  Ocean Voyages and Travels; LincolnCOMMA AbrahamCOMMA 1809-1865--Assassination;
Transcript:
Locust Shade. 5. 27. [18]65

My dear AnnieCOMMA

It seems to me that a very improper time has elapsed since the receipt of they welcome letterCOMMA without my having answered it - but as we are both well hosted in excuses I will not add to the list.- Just as I began my letterCOMMA thy kind note was handed me - & I truly thank thee for it and should love to comply with they request - but [dont] see that it would be possible. Besides dearie I want thee to come here - and hope to persuade thee to do so.- Your place must indeed looklovely & I have thought several times how I should like to look uponits beauty and enjoy your society - which is always so pleasantCOMMA but I must deny myself this time- I want tooCOMMA to hear about the wedding & Clemmy & diverse other things. Our “Strawberry Company” as thee calls itCOMMA is not here- tho we have had several of our friends the past weekCOMMA - and shall probably have more [next]. - - Our cook had gone away for a fortnights visitCOMMA half of the time is gone - at which I rejoiceCOMMA and this is another reason why I cannot leave home- the next week father and mother will be away for a Sundays- and after that I do hope thee will come to see me. Any day that suits thee we shall gladly welcome thee. -

I heard from Deborah Thomas that Clemmy was pleasantly situated and like her occupation.- Thee must miss her visits very much & she thine. - Lily seemsquite absented in her work and is turning out a very managing young lady - it will probably be of great use to her in calling out her latent energies.-

How many remarkable & [steming] events have transpired since we were together.- It seems to me we haveCOMMA every dayCOMMA reason to mourn death of our own dear good President - Johnson is so different - & if he should get us into a Mexican war it would be so sad. But we can but hope for the best. Was it not wonderful how suddenly & completely the Rebellion cam to an end. Like the “One hoss slay”- it all broke down at once.- Poor Jeff makes a sorry figure in his humiliation he is showing very plainly what a poor miserable specimen of a man he was.- Niether true courage or honor in the slightest appreciative of his great crimes. -- We have justhad our Bettie at home for ten days and busy enough we were with her spring clothing - she comes back again the last of next month for vacation.- She is growing so companionable that I miss her when she is gone very much.-
I am glad to hear Uncle D B Smith sometimes gets to your house. no doubt it does him good. Wish I could see him. Will thee give him my love when thee see him.- Suppose Uncle John & Aunt R Smith & cos Lizzie are out in the broad Ocean. we hear our cousin Richard Howland was to go with themCOMMA but do not know if its true. If aunt R’s health is improved - it will be delightful for them all to be together. Would thee not like to go if thee could do so properly? - I should exceedinglyCOMMA but probably never shallCOMMA my life seems destined to be very unadventurous and matter of factCOMMA - all for the best no doubt.- Do Lilly & her Philip’slive in Germantown? What a favored place you live in all the nice people do mostly congregate there. R wishes to be remembered to thee & hopes sometime to accept the very kind invitation. Just now I [----] [------] are all engrossing. - I hope thy father is pretty well this spring please remember me to him.- With much love I am very truly thee thee at[----]
S. S. Reeve

I hope thee has not got any of those little salt sellars yetCOMMA as I have has a pair waiting for thee ever so longCOMMA Will send them down next week if I can. -

Title: 1862 August 7COMMA Scranton PaCOMMA to Alfred Cope Esq
Creator: Charles M. Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875;
Subject: Military serviceCOMMA Voluntary;  Military history; Recruiting   and enlistment; United States--History--Civil WarCOMMA   1861-1865; Family;

Further information about Charles M. Drinker and his family is unavailable in Haverford’s archives.

On the reverse side of the letter is written: C M Drinker 8/62
Transcript:
Scranton Pa Aug 7th. 1862
Alfred Cope Esq
Dear Sir
I write to you to request you to procure for me a Situation in the Navy as Captains Clerk if Possible I should enlist in the Army but I am the only one at home to care for my Mother & Sisters & they object to my so doingCOMMA I may be drafted under the new call & for this reason they will feel satisfied if I can get an opportunity in the Navy as the service is not so hard
very respectfully your friend
Charles M Drinker

Title: 1908 December 10COMMA GermantownCOMMA To Rachel C. Evans
Creator: Sarah W. Rhoads
Subject: Group decision making--Religious aspects--Society of Friends
Transcript:
152 School-house Lane
Germantown

My dear friend
Rachel C. Evans--

I think that I can fully understand thy feelings as expressed in thy touching note of last week--and have waited to replyCOMMA until the Friends having the matter in chargeCOMMA could confer together;
this they did this morning; and now I must tell theeCOMMA that after giving our earnest consideration to the subjectCOMMA the proposal of thy name for this service was our unanimous decision; and I was requested to let thee know that thee had been thought of as most suitableCOMMA by each member of our committee before we mettogether: May we not conclude thereforeCOMMA that this decision is in the right orderingCOMMA according to our best light and JudgmentCOMMA while hoping that thee will be willing to accept it as such.
And now may I personally express my sympathy for theeCOMMA should thee feel it right to serve in this responsible position--and also the desire that thee may realize the words "He giveth forever to the faint; and to them that have no might he increaseth strength."
While I remain with love Sincerely thy friend
Sarah W. Rhoads

Dec--10th 1908

Title: 1865 May 10COMMA BaltimoreCOMMA to Tom
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; ThomasCOMMA Allen C. (Allen Clapp)COMMA 1846-1920; CopeCOMMA E. D. (Edward Drinker)COMMA 1840-1897
Subject: African Americans--History--1863-1877; Patriotic music; Baltimore (Md.)--History; Freedmen--United States; Society of Friends; Freedmen--United States; Women educators; Haverford College--Students; Letter writing; Discipline of children; Music--Instruction and study
Notes:
Tom is Clementine’s brotherCOMMA Alexis Thomas Cope. “Busy” is a nickname for their brother Edgar Cope.

Both “My Native CountryCOMMA Thee” and “The Colored Volunteer” were patriotic songs popular in the mid-nineteenth century. The latter was the regimental song of the Massachusetts 54th Colored RegimentCOMMA later portrayed in the film Glory.
Transcript:
Baltimore 5. 10th. 65

Dear TomCOMMA
Thee must excuse me for having been so long answering thy letterCOMMA & not think that I did not care about itCOMMA for I was right pleased that thee wrote to meCOMMA & I have said to myself ever so many times [said] that I must write to that “Little “Toms”— but thee sees now I have got to be a school mistressCOMMA I have so many cares that I cant always do[o] what I’d like & then I have had a good many letters to write to different people & knowing that thee saw the home ones & knew all about meCOMMA I took it the easier.
I have now been “school”mom=’en” long enough to get a prety good idea of the business – & my idea of it isCOMMA thatits a good deal easier to be a scholar than I teacherCOMMA – so thee can remember that for thy comfort when thee has a hard lesson to learn. To teach a school of troublesome boys I shd. say was one of the hardest businesses’s that cld. well be got up.. The girls are bad enoughCOMMA but when it comes to boys – – they’re the [---] of man. I have in my school about 35 boys & a dozen girls between the ages of 6 & 15 — The girls I have but little trouble withCOMMA but the little boys are regular monkeys. No sooner is my back turned than they begin their discussions of wh. they have a variety — Its the hardest thing in the world to keep them stillCOMMA & if they get a good chance there’s not one of them that is too good to get up & takea dance or a fight or any other such little amusement that they think will set the school in an uproar.+ [+ Throwing spit balls is a very bad habit they have – also dancing “Ham fat”] My punishments are various. Sometimes I shake the culprit & if that wont doCOMMA tie em up hand & foot & put em in the corner — wh. is a very troublesome operation to me. But it seems as if nothing wld. beat it into their heads that school is any thing but a place to play in.
Most of them can read a little some not at allCOMMA & like “Busy” – they must always spell girl gril and dirt – drit –. It seems as if it came natural — One of their best accomplishments is singing wh. we sometimes let them do in school. My children know “my”native country thee” & the colored “Wolunteer”— wh. they shout out with great effect. But I guess I’ve told thee enough about the darkies We’ll talk a little abt.the whites. How comes on work at Haverford? By the way thy hand writing is coming on so wellCOMMA that when I got thy letter I thot. it was Busy’s himselfCOMMA it was so good. Have’nt you a boy named Allen ThomasCOMMA? I expect he’s a nice fellow & has two very nice brothers whom I met last eveng. There are [---] pleasant frieds here & I do not often have a chance to feel lonely or home sick. How does Prof. Cope & his botany lectures? I am going to try to write him a note to send in this & consequently must say farewell or shall not have time. Thee can take this down home with thee next 7th day & tell ‘em it’s all they’ll get this week.— as they dont deserve any for some time. Give my love to allCOMMA & if thee gets time write again to thy affec sister C

Title: 1904 August 25COMMA Duchy LausanneCOMMA to Rachel C. Evans
Creator: Samuel Morris:  1827-1905
Identified People: MorrisCOMMA Hannah PerotCOMMA 1854-1931;        EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA   1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967;
Subject: Health;  Voyages and Travels--Health aspects; Faith;
Geographic Subjects: GenevaCOMMA Lake (Switzerland and France); New England
Transcript:
DuchyCOMMA Lausanne
8/25.1904.

My dear friend
Rachel C. Evans.

In carrying out our program for SwitzerlandCOMMA the weather has suddenly changed from intense heat and a very long drought to a rain of several daysCOMMA which while most grateful to the parched countryCOMMA interferes materially with views of the charming Lake of Geneva and the mountains that environ it. Instead thereforeCOMMA of our usual outdoor lifeCOMMA this gives just the opportunity for which I've been wishingCOMMA to acknowledge some of the very kind farewell greetingsCOMMA received as we left our native shores. The weather being so variableCOMMA it has seemed best for one to remain in this most comfortable Eng.-speaking pensionCOMMA with a delightful out-look upon the LakeCOMMA while my dear Hannah has gone into the
upper regionsCOMMA so as to get into closer touch with their sublime peaks--at least so far as the fickle weather may permit. Meanwhile thereforeCOMMA my pen is giving me congenial occupation in-doors.
Among the loving remembrances to which I have referredCOMMA is thine from FranconiaCOMMA U. N. of [--] 28--I was truly glad also thus to receive good accounts from youCOMMA and can only trust your outing in the bracing air of New Eng. may be permanently helpful to thyself and your dear AnnaCOMMA of whom I often think with tender sympathyCOMMA desiring that "the best of Physicians"--may keep her under his all-wise and loving care. Turning away thereforeCOMMA from misgivingsCOMMA or fearsCOMMA or failures as they may seem to herCOMMA may there be a more "continual looking into Jesus"COMMA not only "as the author"COMMA but "the finisher of her faith". Let her ever remember that it is this same Saviour of our'sCOMMA who has begun his work of grace in her heart that seeks to carry it on and perfect it
to his praiseCOMMA and her unspeakable peace. He knows her better than she knows herself; and thereforeCOMMA none so well as He can "speak to her condition". It is thus He has revealed himself to multitudes of struggling soulsCOMMA and they never seek His face in vain. Then it is that anxiety gives place to a quiet childlike confidence in HimCOMMA and impatience as to a more rapid growth in grace than we may have yet known finds us more continually dwelling upon the abounding love of GodCOMMA and brings about that "patient waiting for Christ"COMMA which the apostle craves for his fellow believers.
While our best desires are turned in this directionCOMMA there is nothing incompatible with the fullest appreciation of the outward favors & blessings with which our Heavenly Father has surrounded us. IndeedCOMMA we now realize that these he has "given us richly to enjoy". We recognize His good hand in them allCOMMA and so a continual thanksgiving goes up from our hearts to HimCOMMA as the all-bountiful giver. I see little to add to the few
hints as aboveCOMMA and would have thee to use them or notCOMMA only as way may open--Indeed I can quite believe thatCOMMA if a fittingCOMMA natural opening does not occurCOMMA it may be best to speak to Anna of nothing beyond my continued loving interest in her.
As to the results of our own ramblingCOMMA I may thankfully say thatCOMMA for myselfCOMMA there seems a marked gain in several respectsCOMMA butCOMMA as thou has intimatedCOMMA the full benefit of such changes is sometimes felt later. My dear Hannah could scarcely be in better condition for enjoying to the full the scenes of rare interest and beauty thr'o which we are and have been passing. I think howeverCOMMA we shall both be glad when the time for our return voyage shall have come. This will be 10/5COMMA by the "Haverford"COMMA for PhilaCOMMA and shortly afterCOMMA if the Lord willCOMMA we may hope to be once more among our dear home friends--Please remember us in love to Jon.COMMA while I remain

very sincerely thy friend
Sam Morris

Title: 1864 August 31COMMA SpringfieldCOMMA MassCOMMA to Papa and Mama
Creator: Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; CopeCOMMA RuthannaCOMMA 1834-1879; HartshorneCOMMA Anna C. (Anna Cope)COMMA 1860-1957; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897; HartshorneCOMMA Mary Elizabeth BrownCOMMA b. 1823
Subject: Clothing and dress; Railroads; Health; Family; Quakers--Travel; Voyages and Travels; New England--Description and travel
Geographic Subjects: New England; Springfield (Mass.); Newport (R.I.); Worcester (Mass.); HolyokeCOMMA Mount (Mass.); New Haven (Conn.)
Notes: This letter is edited in inkCOMMA probably in E.S.C.’s own hand at a later date.
Transcript:
Springfield. Mass. Aug. 31st
4th day eve.

Dear Papa & MamaCOMMA
We rec’d your letters this morning just as we started & were very glad to get themCOMMA tho’ sorry to think they came too late to engage rooms for you at the Cliff House we were very anxious to hear from you in timeCOMMA but you were so long making up your mindsCOMMA that we almost came to the conclusion you were not going to at allCOMMA & had given it up. However Uncle H. thinks there will be no trouble in getting them by writing afterwards. We left Newport at 7 o’clock this morning & dined at Worcester very comfortably about 2 o’clock & arrived here at 6 1/2 about. Thishotel is delightfulCOMMA they say it is one of the best in the Union Sallie Parish says “its where all the brides come toCOMMA” I haven’t seen any yet! We got a splendid supper & Uncle Harry & Chell & I took a little stroll through the town it seems very pretty as far as gas and star-light would show. But me thinks we will not see much more of itCOMMA we propose leaving quite early tomorrow morning for [Mt.] Holyoke. Aunt Mary says “that all things considered she is certainly remarkably wellCOMMA” last 1st day she says she felt better than she has for a year. She is certainly improvedCOMMA but don’t raise your hopes to high or I fear you will be disappointed – She’s betterCOMMA but not well.
They are talkingCOMMA talking! all the timeCOMMA & I can’t writeCOMMA Aunt [K]. has a very nice room on the secondfloorCOMMA & ChellCOMMA GinnieCOMMA & I have three cots put up in an adjoining private parlorCOMMA its quite fine we’re all seated round the centre table with a bright gas-light above us & a velvate carpet beneath usCOMMA & the most delightful easy chairs aren’t we splendid?
Uncle H. says our present intention is to come home in the 2 o’cl train 7th day (if the time-table is right) I think we’ll not get out [--] 4COMMA if we change our plans we’ll telegraph. Now Mother I must stop for I want to fix my hat & its getting late. Aunt M. says she would have written but she has been retrimming Anna’s hat & had no time. Love to all
very affec’ly
Lillie

P.S. Resolved-that we take dinner at Aunt [Annas]COMMA & come in quarter before 4P.S. resolved that you need not expect us till we come
P.S. thats wrong!
P.S. We will probably come out in the 9 o’clock cars taking tea at the Continental.
P.S. Still talking can’t tell if this be the final decision!
P.S. Final decision! Seriously! It is extremely difficult to fix our plansCOMMA & we will positively come home on 7th day either 1/4 4 or 9 o’cl trains.
P.S. Uncle Harry thinks we ought to give a reason for our indecision. Reason That we can not find beforehand how long it will take to visit Mt. Holyoke as we have to drive part of the wayCOMMA & that makes it uncertain whether we will reach New Haven tomorrow night or the next day

Title: 1864 June 4COMMA Rockview CottageCOMMA to Anne
Creator: Martha Leeds:  1810?-1888
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Rachel ReeveCOMMA 1794-1863;        CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA   1793-1865; ThomasCOMMA George HenryCOMMA 1816-1870; McMichaelCOMMA   MortonCOMMA 1807-1879; LeedsCOMMA Lewis W. (Lewis Walker) ca.   1827-1896;
Unidentified People: Dr and Anna HarlowCOMMA Robert A. and Ellen ParrishCOMMA Dr.Janney’s daughterCOMMA Dr RidgleyCOMMA BenCOMMA Col. CulverCOMMA Capt.Edwards
Subject: Outdoor recreation;  Health; Weather; Death; Nature; United   States--History--Civil WarCOMMA 1861-1865; Bereavement;
Geographic Subjects: Lookout Mountain (Appalachian Mountains); Chattanooga   (Tenn.); Philadelphia (Pa.); TennesseeCOMMA East; Pennsylvania
Notes:
Related files:
lewismarthaleeds.tif (picture of their cabin on Lookout Mountain sometime during the Civil War)

hsc0020f (extensive research notes compiled by Janet Bunde)
Transcript:
Rockview Cottage
6 mo 4th 1864 –

My dear AnneCOMMA

From cloud land do I now address thee it has been rainingCOMMA raining for days – but we cannot wish it otherwise as it will raise the mountain springs which were beginning to fail rapidly it has been rather an anxious care with us to watch the springs for fear they would give out before the cisterns were prepared to save the water and the steam pumps were fixed so that the pure water might be available for the sick in the Hospitals there are but about 500 patients now but it is hoped that the large field Hospital at Chattanooga may soon be moved up here and probably two thirds of the patients that would otherwise die might recover I think there had been but four deaths since the Hospital was established here The air is so fine and the water runningthrough sand stone rocks the sweetest that could be and I sometimes think the patients would recover without medicine – Several patients extremely ill with pneumonia have lived although Dr H said they must die –
When it does clear I expect we shall have one of these magnificent cloud scenes – Sunshine and blue sky above whilst below us a billowy sea of clouds looking as if they were frozen as they formed – I imagine it must look precisely like an Artic sea – We have witnessed two such scenes when it had been raining heavily – the whole valley completely hid except about half way up the Mountain – Anna Harlow is describing some of the cloud scenes we have had beautifully alluded to the psalm where they are so grandly described and which we can appreciate from having witnessed the clouds in their grandeurabove and below us as well as like the present time we have been for days enveloped in the thick clouds – "The waters stood above the mountains At Thy rebuke they fled – at the voice of thy thunder they hasted away – They go up by the Mountains they go down by the valleys unto the place which thou hast founded for them – He watereth the hills from his chambers" &c– There are many beautiful scenes so much so that I could not picture them to thee – I know thee would enjoy many of the views that are on every handCOMMA not only from their beauty but from the historic interest that even now induces people by hundreds to come up the Mountain to see the celebrated "Lookout" and the scenes in the valley below us – I never was at a more charming place I think – The other day some ladies from Philada. Ellen Parrish sister to Robert A Parrish and Dr Janney’s daughter spent two days at our house (and rather inconvenientlyCOMMAtwo nights as we were obliged to give up our room and our husbands had to sleep on the floor – they had come on a mission of relief to E Tennessee refugees and had become acquainted with the Commander of the post Col Culver who offerred them facilities to go to the Lake and Falls about six miles distant – Lewis & myself accompanied the party – It was a scene of rare beauty – The Falls are not large but very high and fall in shimmering spray down the most beautiful rocks – It seemed to me as though every thing had been brought to bear to make the place charming The rocks of various hues and shaded seemed cut into the most picturesque forms whilst the clear mountain stream came over its clean and clear rocky bed & went down the precipice to the height of 125 feet – Another face below us which we could discover by the Mist we did not get to visit –The slopes were covered with Rhodedendron of very large flower and Laurels and the [Fringe] tree growing wild – We came away reluctantly and all of us thought I have no doubt that we either would visit it again or would more than ever desire to do so – The next day being First day our neighbours Dr Ridgleys who had been up but a few days started to go there on horseback there were six of them one of the party told me that she went feeling rather afraid that it was not right – they had got quite a distance beyond the pickets and they must have been very near the Falls I judge when as they were a little off the roadside resting off their horses they saw a man dressed in Rebel uniformCOMMA grey cloth and brass buttons passed right by them [leading] his horse and did not take notice of them – one of the gentlemen called after him after he passed – "My kind sir where do you belong?" he repliedat General Thomas’ Headquarters. They all believed him to be a rebel officer and as he had a large revolver and they were unarmed he could have captured the whole of them – they were pretty much frightened and concluded to turn their horses heads homeward and did not see the Falls – so much for their pleasure party on First day – In speaking of it it was remarked that sometimes our scouts go dressed in Rebel uniform – it might have been one of them – There is another very beautiful place called "Rock City"– The brow of this Mountain is crowned with soft kind of Rocks which look as if some day had been washed and rounded by water covering them – Geologists would say they had – At Rock City these rocks cover the groundCOMMA at one place like a town and at another we walked over them and gathered the most beautifullichens and mosses x_COMMA red green & drabCOMMA [x with most remarkable fissures & clefts all through them] I only wish we could send you some specimens – I think we might by "Adams Express" sometime before we go away when the facilities [of] transportation are more available than they are here at present there have been some moms gathered and sent to the different Fairs for the benefit of the Sanitary Com. as well as lots of Canes– The roots of the Laurel are very hard and beautifully grained large quantities are dug and articles made of them as mementoes of the place – Our Ben has quite a lot which the soldiers gave him when they went to the Front – which he sells as well as canes to increase his fortune –
Thee may be very sure that I was much gratified upon receiving thy kind little note – I had not forgotten my promise to write to thee but supposing thee often heard from us through my Children I did not know whetherthee cared particularly about my writing added to which I rather feel averse to tell the same thing over again – although there is not any lack of incident here – We have been living very quietly here the past three months – We have had some acquisitions to the place lately but need not feel alarmed at their being very extensiveCOMMA without people build for themselves or live in tents – As I raise my eyes I see the tents of Major Mc’Michael and one or two others in the woods at one side of us – they look very pretty – he is Adjat to Gen Thomas – is the son of Morton McMichael of Philada. on the other side is the cottage of Dr Ridgley Medical Purveyor with two ladies boarding with them and Capt Edwards from Penn Wife & daughter who board with one of the old residents are all the Society here except ourselves A part of an Engineer Brigade about600 men the Officers Hospital of 100 men and convalescents of the number of 400 are all that live here except three or four families who have remained through all and are entirely dependent for provision for what they can purchase through exchange – They sell their milk at from 50 cts to $1.00 per gal eggs 75 cts per doz butter 75 cts per lb and have been getting in exchange from us flour at 3 1/2 cts per lb sugar 14 cts per lb – They charge for butter milk 75 & 80 cts per gal and can get it readily as it is so desirable for the sick –
I have often recurred to the time I spent at your house last Spring when I was with you in sympathy by the Suffering bed of thy dear Mother – I never witnessed such suffering and I never recur to it perhaps but with Something of the tender feelingsthat then pervaded my heart – I dare say thee often feels lonely without her dear Anne – but no doubt thee thinks that thy loss is her gain and that she would not wish to exchange her bliss in Heaven for any earthly thing – there was a great deal that was pleasant and sweet that she left below – Many that have the tastes to enjoy the beautiful could not have them gratified like the inmates of such a home as you have but with it all I often felt sorrowful that dear sister was deprived of the use of her eyes which to me would have been terrible – but all things have been ordered aright we cannot doubt – I would be very glad to hear from thee as often as thee feels like writing to thy absent but not the less interested and affectionate
Aunt Martha –
Please give my love to Father and all the inmates of your home –

Title: 1771 July 13COMMA BristolCOMMA to Mary Sandwith
Creator: Elizabeth Sandwith Drinker:  1734-1807
Identified People: DeNormandieCOMMA John Abraham; DrinkerCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1734-1809; DrinkerCOMMA Henry SandwithCOMMA 1770-1824
Unidentified People: Doctor Denormandie; DivineCOMMA Mag.; Doctor Evans; FoulkeCOMMA Molly; HodgeCOMMA Billy; HoffmanCOMMA Sally; Le GayCOMMA S.; [Pintard]COMMA Boudinott; [Parr]COMMA Caleb; [Parr]COMMA Nancy; ParrCOMMA Billy; [Parr]COMMA Peggy; PintardCOMMA Sukey; [R]ingoldCOMMA T. and wife; TilghmanCOMMA serli and Betsy; TredwellCOMMA Sally; Patty; Billy Coxe’s daughter; Henry and Elizabeth Drinker’s 9 children (according to DQB); James
Subject: Child rearing;  Infants--Weaning; Breast feeding; Family; Health; Women domestics; Physicians--United States--History--18th century; Women patients; Faith
Geographic Subjects: Bristol (Pa.); Bath (Pa.); Trenton (N.J.); Philadelphia (Pa.); Maryland; New York (State)
Notes: Letter written in three separate sittings.
Transcript:
Bristol July 13. 1771 – 7th day 1 oClock
My dear Sister

My Henry came here last evening in seeming good spirits but indifferent Health; he eat a very light supperCOMMA and sett off this morning (after a poor breakfast) about 8 oClock. He has a fine dayCOMMA and I hope riding and relaxation from business will restore him; he talked of returning to Bristol on 5th day or perhaps not untill 7th day next. Thy continued Confinement and constant care give me many an anxious minute; but I trust the time will come when it may please kind Providence to make things easier to thee. I was not quite so well yesterday as usual & my dear Henrys coming to me so unwell gave me pain. I am quite bravely to day after coming out of the water but full of thought about my dear little crowing Henry. Doct. D.* [*Denormandie] came here last eveningCOMMA andCOMMA after the usual salutationCOMMA said to meCOMMA he was come to have some serious talk with me; I smiled; nay said he I am in earnest; about what Doctor? – weaning your little son; such a hearty growing boyCOMMA who seems to live upon youCOMMA is enough to draw a pain in a weakly personCOMMA where there had never been one before; besides he keeps you waking at nightsCOMMA and prevents your using means that might restore you; if it was not on his account you might now go with Mr. Drinker to the sea shoreCOMMA and so forth. There are several women here who I beleive have put it into the Doctors head that I ought not to suckle the Child. My Henry seconded himCOMMA and said he would write this morning to theeCOMMA but as he was poorlyCOMMA I undertook to do it.– Do not think my dearCOMMA from what I have writtenCOMMA that I am worse; Indeed I am not through mercyCOMMA but have had the pain in my breast oftener than I had sometime agoCOMMA which I told the Doctor. I beleive that if I had a Girl with me that was worth a figCOMMA it would be differentCOMMA for the one I have has no knack of making the Child fond of her. Doctr. D. says as Doctr. Evans knows my ConstitutionCOMMA he would have him spoken to. – I would have thee see the Doctor and talk with him. Patty would do a great deal better than the Girl I haveCOMMA and should she offer againCOMMA I would not have thee entirely discourage herCOMMA but tell her thee beleives the girl I have does not suit meCOMMA and if she thinks she can behave so as to please meCOMMA thee would have her call again. It will be time enough (after theehas spoken to Doct. Evans) to come to any conclusion when my Henry returns. I had a room full of visitors yesterday afternoon; two Chariotts full besides others; T. Ringold & Wife from Maryland; Sally HoffmanCOMMA Sukey PintardCOMMA her sister Boudinott from New York; Serlis’ wifeCOMMA Betsy Tilghman from Philada. and Billy Coxe’s daughterCOMMA and Sally Tredwell the Doctors sister. We all went in the evening to Bath. I go but little a visitingCOMMA and they all think that my little dear keeps me at homeCOMMA and every ones cry is wean himCOMMA wean him; thee would be charmed to see the dear little fellowCOMMA how he daily improves in cunning antick tricks. I long to see thee and my dear ChildrenCOMMA but dont know how to bring it about. My Henry was saying that he was well pleased that I did not get his letter by Billy Hodge (as he had mentioned thy being unwell) as thee is now better. – I would have thee my dear take half a spoonful of the Elixir every day to strengthen thee. I have not had occasion to take any since I came up as yetCOMMA but thee knows it was of great use to me taken in small quantity. I have been but a little while writing thus farCOMMA but as I have not stopped since I beganCOMMA I grow tiredCOMMA and my dear little one is crying for me; My dear love is to thee & to my sweet ChildrenCOMMA to whom I intend to write when I can conveniently; they must not be impatientCOMMA but good and kind to each otherCOMMA & very dutiful & mindful of their Aunty’s willCOMMA which will give great pleasure to their very affectionate mammy
I amCOMMA my dear SisterCOMMA thine &c –
E. Drinker

My dearCOMMA dearCOMMA kind Henry looked so unwell as he slept this morning as made my heart ache; he was last night more than commonly chearfulCOMMA which I have observed often to be the case when he is unwell. how unlike the generality of Mankind is he in his natural disposition many ways. he was last night at supper affectionately acknowledging thy tender care of himCOMMA & saying how clever it was to have two Wives. We were likewise wishing that it was convenient to thee to spend one month hereCOMMA free from care of us & ours. – I hope it may please God to spare me and restore me to health for my Henrys sakeCOMMA & that I may be enabled to make up in some measure to my dear Husband and Sister their manyCOMMA many kindnesses to me; but shouldshould it happen otherwiseCOMMA may I be enabled to sayCOMMA the Lords will be done. –

5 oClock – Billy Parr has been here; he says he saw theeCOMMA & that you are all well. he has gone to TrentonCOMMA where PeggyCOMMA Nancy and Caleb are to go tomorrow; they want me to goCOMMA but I shall not. Molly Foulke is expected here this evening or in the morning. Mag. Divine next second dayCOMMA so that we shall have the house full. Peggy gives her love to thee. Henry’s asleepCOMMA & I am going to Bath. farewell my dear Sister for the present.
E.D.
I wrote yesterday by S. Le GayCOMMA which letter I suppose thee has received. I make no doubt but my dear Henry will return bravely. tomorrow will be a lonesome day to me. my love to neighbour James –
E.D.Bristol July 13. 1771
Elizabeth Drinker to Mary Sandwith

Title: 1876 August 16COMMA SunnysideCOMMA MayfieldCOMMA near AshbourneCOMMA to My dear Friend
Creator: Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
