Title: 1911 March 27COMMA WesttownCOMMA to Boys
Creator: Davis H. (Davis Hoopes) Forsythe:  1858-1934
Recipient: EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977
Subject: Child rearing; Death notices; God;
Notes: Letter of condolence upon the death of Jonathan Evans.
Transcript:
Westtown Pa.
3 mo 27th 1911

Dear Boys

This morning's mail brings to me a sad letter from your cousin Elizabeth Goodhue. It is my last wish to intrude upon your sorrow but I must make just a few words for my sake if not for yours.

The greatesttrial of my life & even yet in retrospect it seems very greatCOMMA your father was the very embodiment of kindness to meCOMMA the sort of kindness that allows your weakness to grow a little stronger from his strength & this and more than thisif possible he was to me. I rememberCOMMA it was many years agoCOMMA the summer before Algernon went to CollegeCOMMA your dear father said to me in the school house office "I did not sleep last nightCOMMA for the thought of the responsibility of the rear-ing of these children of mine got so on my nerve that it banished sleep." I could ask for no better legacy for you dear fellows than that a father would wrestle in prayer the night through that God's blessing might rest on you & on his effort. He answered that prayer & long ago gave your father the assurance that he sought. I could write on and on for Icannot help mingling my tears with yours. With a messageof love to you mother & to Anna.
Your Friend

Davis H. Forsythe

Title: 1899 April 26COMMA RosemontCOMMA to Lily
Creator: Hannah Rhoads Haines Garrett:  1846-1901
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1876-1899; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939;
Subject: Bereavement; Children; Death; God; Health;
Notes: Letter of condolence upon the death of Agnes Cope.
Transcript:
4 mo 26. 1899

Dear LilyCOMMA

There has been a lack of vocal or written sympathy with thee this winterCOMMA and this brief message is only to assure thee of my love and frequent thought being freshly flowing.That mere words would only weary thee I know and I only sent messages to thee by notes to Rachel. It was my hope that long before this my own strength would have retuned and enabled me to go to thee. But that is not the case as only a very little exertion ispossible yet - writingCOMMA almost is a lost art. Excuse this detailCOMMA because I could not otherwise explain my absence. Now we have heard of Edward's illnessCOMMA and I wish to send by thee my love to Jonathan and RachelCOMMA when it is convient to thee.

We Also understand Edward is much beterCOMMA I hope convalescent.DearCOMMA believe meCOMMA thy loss is shared in some degree by meCOMMA for thy lovely Agnes was especially near to meCOMMA her gentle pure spirit now a lasting place in my heart.

She always seemed as one apart from our every-day routineCOMMA and now she is in full & glourious development of all her Savoir has prepared her to be for Him. Always lovingly thy
Hannah R. Garrett.

Title: 1873 August 15COMMA Wolfrun FarmCOMMA to LillyCOMMA Bar Harbour
Creator: Hannah Rhoads Haines Garrett:  1846-1901
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939;
Unidentified People: John; Harry; H.B.E.; S.E. Marshall; Mary and Francis;
Subject: Bereavement; Children; Weddings;
Transcript:
Wolfrun Farm 8 mo 15. 1873

My very dear LillyCOMMA

How many times lately has thee been in my thoughts and very pleasantly too. But owing to my peregrinations with the childrenCOMMA I have been unable to send thee a single greeting of love and good wishes. When John came out to MarpleCOMMA and told me that one of my friends was announced as inelligibleCOMMA I turned to thee at onceCOMMA and said not toCOMMA with immense disapprobation and disbeliefCOMMA and then revived mydrooping spirits with Oh! Alexis Cope! NoCOMMA my dearCOMMA though I gave thee a sight of good advice in good faithCOMMA on Chellie's wedding dayCOMMA about the opportune moment when house and grounds were in perfectionCOMMA I was too modest to suppose it would sink so deep into thy heartCOMMA and show such good fruit so soon. Many thanks my dearCOMMA for they acceptance of my wishes as well as those of some one's else; and hope indeed thee will continue to follow my wishes when they again happen to coincide with thy own. This is destined to be a memorable year among my nearest friendsCOMMA andone full of happines in its future consequences to HarryCOMMA JohnnyCOMMA Chellie and thyself. How I wish to have a look at theeCOMMA and see with my eyes the happiness I feel sure must be thine. Am I to have no single friends leftCOMMA my mind turns to H.B.E. and S.E. Marshall. I hope they will do nothing rashCOMMA and bring home some German counts or English baronets with them. How much better we think it is not to risk our future to a strangerCOMMA but with those whom we can trustCOMMA & know all about their home life.

As I look at Mary and Francis I begin to feel asympathy for thy motherCOMMA thus "bereaved of her children"COMMA as "I look in the future far as human eye can see" and think of the possibility that some pair of boys now fond of candy and fire-crackers may one summer turn their attention to destorying my house-hold harmony and peace-alas!

Now I've written a deal of nonsense and a fear of Alexis comes before meCOMMA lest he has already imbued thee with dignifed scorn for such silliness. Do not betray me thenCOMMA or I will whisper some of thy lightmindness in times past when I've a chance not that he would believe if I did I do long for some news from the European partyCOMMAare they having a prosperous summer? With love to thy mother and thy self I am as ever thy warmly attached.

H.R. GarrettElizabeth S. Cope
Bar Harbour
East Eden
Maine

Title: 1883 September 30COMMA GermantownCOMMA to Carrie
Creator: M.H. Garrett
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; CopeCOMMA EdgarCOMMA 1838-1895; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; MorrisCOMMA SamuelCOMMA 1827-1905; AldersonCOMMA Eleanor Tyson Yarnall; GarrettCOMMA Alfred CopeCOMMA 1867-1946
Unidentified People: Joseph Rhoads; Fanny Garrett; Dr Rhoads;
Subject: Bereavement; Bible--study and teaching; Children; Death; Health; School; Westtown Boarding School;
Transcript:
GermantownCOMMA 9.30.83.

My Dear Carrie-
I hope the expression of sympathy & affection may be acceptableCOMMA even though there may be no new thoughts of comfort to suggest.

I was so sorry to hear from Sister Lillie today that Edgar's health had been poor. I though of him as a strong man. It will be a pleasureCOMMA no doubtCOMMA though mingled with sadnessCOMMA to Nettie & theeCOMMA to minister to the comfort of your remaining brother.

The memory of Alexis is one of calmness & sweetness. I did not know him wellCOMMA yet recall with pleasure the queit cordiality of his greeting. Samuel MorrisCOMMA who rode in the same carriagewith me at the funeralCOMMA said he had learned to love him much. I think it is grateful to look back on his life here as a happy oneCOMMA & his life there as is fit & glorious consummation. And he left a dear legacy in his children. I am glad you have them. I count myself so rich in my dear nephews & niecesCOMMA my young brothers & sistersCOMMA as I sometimes call them. Does thee know I am a great-aunt? My oldest nephewCOMMA Joseph RhoadsCOMMA has a wee EdgarCOMMA away out in Plainfield IndianaCOMMA where he has gone to teach. Hetty is out thereCOMMA helping. Has been away nearly 7 weeks & we don't know when we shall get her back. She went to help furnish & arrange the new little home.

Fanny & Alfred Garret were here last evening a while. We do think Fannya very lively have characterCOMMA & Alfred seems to be coming out a fine manly boyCOMMA & doing well at college.

How the time does fleet away! Think of it being 50 years since we were at West-town together! And what can those fleeting years show? For meCOMMA a life made up of many little thingsCOMMA & with too many idle hours. I enjoy my work of various kinds though; simple household caresCOMMA an extensive correspondenceCOMMA partly for pleasant sympathiesCOMMA partly for teachingCOMMA & on the rest daysCOMMA a restful work in the care of my first-day class. Dr. Rhoads holds a school at our house and I have as my class nearly 20 boys & girls from 9 to 14 years old who troop up to my room with me. I will not claim to do them much good. I don't believe in direct religious teaching exceptwhere there is an opening for itCOMMA but I think the hour passes not unprofitablyCOMMA & they learn to find the study of the Bible pleasant.
I hope Ellie Alderson may continue to improve. I should be glad to hear from thee if thee can feel like writingCOMMA & to be told what your prospects are.
With Love to Nettie & ThyselfCOMMA
ever thy affectionate friend

M. H. Garrett

Title: 1812 May 21COMMA WilmingtonCOMMA to Wm. D CopeCOMMA New Garden
Creator: William C. Geddes
Identified People: LukensCOMMA CharlesCOMMA 1786-1825;
Subject: United States--History--War of 1812; Skating;
Notes: JLC watermark.
Transcript:
Wilmington May 21st 1812

Esteemed Friend

As I have such an excellent opportunity of writing to you I thought it would be a shame to let escape but I have nothing to inform you of any importance excepting [---] great rejoicing here on account of the declaration of war
I saw Jacob Haines yesterday afternoon he is very well and informed me he intended returning to your good friend Kents you heard C. Lukens was teaching school and I Palmer also is.

I would be obliged to you if you would look for my skates and send them down by the first opportunity. Please to answer this soon as you can. Remember me to James Smith and all the others.

Excuse this for it is wrote in haste. I remain your sincere friend

William C. GeddesMr. Wm. D Cope
New-garden
Pennsylvania

Title: 1909 November 8COMMA to Thomas
Creator: Phebe E.H. Haines
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862;
Subject: Death notices; Death--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Poetry;
Notes:
Letter of condolence and remembrence upon the death of Francis R. Cope.
Acrostic by Francis R. Cope written upon the death of Haines' father (Joseph Howell).
Transcript:
My dear Thomas:-

As my thoughts have gone out in sympathy for thee in the great loss of thy dear fatherCOMMA I have recalled an acrostic which he wrote for my mother after my father's deathCOMMA just twenty years ago; and which we valued very much. I think it is most touchingly beautifulCOMMA especially soCOMMA that it now seems almost prophetic of his own entranceinto the heavenly city.
"Joined to the loved ones whoCOMMA expectant longCOMMA
On yonder shore his coming did awaitCOMMA
Singing their jubilantCOMMA thanksgiving songCOMMA
Early & lateCOMMA before the pearly gateCOMMA
Palms in their hands; And robed in spotless
whiteCOMMA
Happy to praise their Savior day and night!
How must his soul have thrilled with raptureCOMMA
when
On quicken earCOMMA burst the ecstatic song!
With what transporting joyCOMMA behold again
Earths lost ones gathered in that Heavnely
throng!
LovingCOMMA as only ransomed spirits loveCOMMA
Love centered in Him who is Eternal love."

Please give my love & sympathy to thy mother and sisters andBelieve meCOMMA with sincere sympathy.

Thy FriendCOMMA
Phebe E. H. Haines

5433 Wayne Ave.
11 mo. 8th. 1909.

Title: 1895 September 1COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Annette
Creator: Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth Waln StokesCOMMA 1823-1902; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; HartshorneCOMMA Virginia;
Unidentified People: Nanna; gentleman from Dai Nippon; Dr. Norris; a German doctor;
Subject: Family; Quakers--Social life and customs; Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Germantown (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.); Italy; Japan; Philadelphia (Pa.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.);
Notes: The sorrow of which Hartshorne speaks is likely a reference to the death of Edgar Cope.
Transcript:
Woodbourne
Sept. 1st 1895

My dear AnnetteCOMMA

When I reached Holmhurst last week Nanna immediately presented me with thy packageCOMMA and I opened and found the irresistable little gentleman from Dai Nippon. Where did thee pick him upCOMMA I wonder! He will be a most pleasant memento of theeCOMMA though I shall hesitate to insult his diginity by inkinghis fine skirts! I have thought of theeCOMMA and of you all so much this summerCOMMA and greatly wished I could have seen thee and Carrie before we leave. I hoped Mrs. Cope would return while I was at HolmhurstCOMMA but she is I supppose still with you. If so please give her my dear love. Thee will forgive me I know for this tardy workCOMMA I spent a whole week nominally at HolmhurstCOMMA actually between the cityCOMMA GermantownCOMMA and all the [---]. Thee knows onlytoo well what such packing is. Now I am enjoying a few day's rest at Woodbourne before going back to Awbury for a square start westward. Virginia here and sends her loveCOMMA also says to tell thee that I will meet thee in Italy winter after next. I tell her I give the message as hersCOMMA not mine! Much as I should like such a prospect; she is much more liekly to turn up there in the next year or twoCOMMA than I! Lillie and the girls & Thos. & Elizabeth Cope are entertaining Dr. Norris and a Germandoctor friend in the parlorCOMMA else they would doubtless send messages. Please give my love to Carrie and ClementineCOMMA I understand you are all togetherCOMMA and are glad to know you have that comfort. With dear love for thy own selfCOMMA and thanks for thinking of me amid so much sorrowCOMMA I am as alwaysCOMMA

Affectionally thine
Anne C. Hartshorne

Title: 1909 November 10COMMA to Aunt Anna
Creator: Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897; HartshorneCOMMA Mary Elizabeth BrownCOMMA b. 1823;
Subject: Death notices; Family; Letter writing;
Notes: Letter of rememberence upon the death of Francis R. CopeCOMMA husband of Anna S. Cope.
Transcript:
16 [---]
Nov-10-1909

Dearest Aunt AnnaCOMMA

There is nothing to say to thee but that I think of thee all the timeCOMMA and long to be near thee instead of on the other side of the earth. The letters with any definite news will be very slow in comingCOMMA as these of mine must seem late and longin reaching you. But thee knowsCOMMA and you all knowCOMMA how my heart is with you. I have been thinking of Father’s last message to his "more than brother"COMMA and of what both he and thee have been to me all my life. From my babyhood thee has made me feel almost as much thy child as mother’s and to me it seems those tiesare not broken but made strong for eternityCOMMA where our beloved cross to the Beyond. My desire is to be worthy of such an inheritance of affliction as mine. My love can never repay itCOMMA but that thee has always.

Ask some to write me a line when they can. My Love to them all.

Thy always loving nieceCOMMA
Anna C. Hartshorne

Title: 1860 May 8
Creator: Charles Hartshorne:  1829-1908
Recipient: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909
Identified People: CopeCOMMA William BrownCOMMA 1854-1860;
Subject: Bereavement; Death--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; God; Poetry;
Notes:
DELARUE & Co. LONDON embossing.
Poem marking the death of William Brown CopeCOMMA son of Francis R. and Anna S. Cope.
Transcript:
Six years agoCOMMA when ever joyous Spring
scattered rich gifts upon this earth of our's
Far sweeter than the sweetest of her flowersCOMMA
One flower did God to our own garden bring.

He planted it a noble plantCOMMA and gave
The charge of it into our loving careCOMMA
To train it tenderlyCOMMA so it might bear
Fruit to His praise who for such fruit I did crave.

Ah! how kept we our trust? Was ours the loveCOMMA
Which while it prized the gift loved more the givenCOMMA
And sought with tearsCOMMA how is might best deliver
The entrusted talent back to him above?

Oh! earthly loveCOMMA oh! selfish human heartCOMMA
Weak and mistrustful of God's providence
Troubled for many things of time and senseCOMMA
Yet careless of the one thing needfulCOMMA the good path!

Therefore when God our ill kept graden sawCOMMA
And marked how weeds were climbing o’er the flowers
So that the refreshing Heavenly showers
Might hardly reach them; gently did he draw

One flower from our keepingCOMMA it may be
Not only to preserve that one from harmCOMMA
But that our careless souls be might alarmCOMMA
And waken from their false security.
Ah me! How little had we dreamed of this
! ListlessCOMMA beside our cherished flowers we lay.
And as we breathed their fragrance day by day.
Looked for no pride awakening from own bliss.

In distant meadows could we often hear
The stern old mower what his fatal sythe;
But yet our hearts beat ever free & blytheCOMMA
Since to our garden still he drew not near.

Angel of Death! Ah! who may ever tell
The bitter anguish of our soulsCOMMA but now
No doubt can e'er disturb our faith that thou
Wast sent by Him who doeth all things well.

He called our flower Willie; twas a name
Borne by one dearly lovedCOMMA whose gentle heart
Waited e'en then the summons to depart;
And joyfully received it when it came.

And we had hopedCOMMA that in our brother's stead
Our darling might be found by name & all
His guiltless actionsCOMMA ever to recall
The cherised memories of the loved & dead.

Such was wour hope; yet may we not repine;
Twas matchless wisdom and unbounded love
Drew both our precious ones to him above;
To make them in His Heavenly courts to shine.
Now other names we trust to them are givenCOMMA
In that blest land where our loved flower is growing.
The stream of life beside him ever ever flowingCOMMA
Which maketh glad the heritage of Heaven.

And now on this his Natal DayCOMMA
We humbly bend the kneeCOMMA and pray
To TheeCOMMA who wast his God alwaysCOMMA
God of all ConsolationCOMMA

That thou our hearts may so inclineCOMMA
So bend our stubborn wills to thineCOMMA
That we no longer may repine
In our deep tribulation

We thank Thee GodCOMMA that Thou hast taken
Our Willie from this world of painCOMMA
Before upon his robes the stain
Of deadly sin did cling.

And in his sweet simplicityCOMMA
That thouCOMMA most precious thoughts of Thee
And of Thy HeavenCOMMA continuallyCOMMA
Before his mind did bring.

overSoCOMMA when thy summons to him cameCOMMA
While suffering racked his tender frameCOMMA
The call was welcomeCOMMA as the claim
Of friend long dearly known.

An doubting naughtCOMMA his willing feet
Hastened the messenger to meetCOMMA
As one he trustingly could greetCOMMA
Who came to take him home.

Oh Lord! Thou gainest the victory!
Not unto himCOMMA but unto Thee
Let all the praise and honor be
OhCOMMA Lord! our God most glorius!

Oh! In the darkness of our night
When we too wage the fearful fightCOMMA
May we be made through thy blessed lightCOMMA
Like him o'er death victorious.

5th month 8th 1860.

Title: 1911 May 24COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Rachel C. Evans
Creator: Charles James Rhoads:  1872-1956
Identified People: EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911;
Subject: Bereavement; Death notices; Haverford College--History;
Notes: Letter of sympathy on behalf of Haverford College's Board of Managers upon the death of Manager Jonathan Evans.
Transcript:
5. 24. 1911

Rachel C. Evans
My Dear CousinCOMMA

I enclose herewith copy of minutes adopted at the last meeting of the Board of Managers of Haverford College and which I was directed to send to thee.

I cannot tell thee how I missed cousin Jonathan at this meeting. He wasone of those I always counted on for sympathy and enouragement.

Sincerely thineCOMMA
CJ RhoadsI hereby certify that the following is a true and correct copy from the minutes of action taken at a meeting of the Board of Managers of THE CORPORATION OF HAVERFORD COLLEGE held 5th Month 19thCOMMA 1911.

The President reminded the Board that since our last meeting two of our fellow Managers had had been taken from us by deathCOMMA and it was unanimously resolved that the following minutes be entered on our records.

On 3rd Month 26thCOMMA 1911COMMA Jonathan Evans passed away in his 67th year. He was elected a Manager of this Corporation on 10th Month 12thCOMMA 1897COMMA and continued in active service until his death. We shall always remember his as one who loved his fellow menCOMMA which trait endeared him to those with whom he came in contact. For many years he took a lively interest in all the out-door activites at the College and by frequent visits to the campus kept himself informed of the condition and needs of the grounds and buildings. On this account his judment on question that came before us was the more valuable because it was based on personal knowledge. He was personally known to many of the studentsCOMMA who were often helped by his affectionate sympathy with all their interests. His fellow Managers will truly miss his presence at their meetingsCOMMA at which he was a faithful and regular attendant.***********
Charles J Rhoads
Secretary.

Title: 1911 March 25COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Algie
Creator: Alfred G. (Alfred Garrett) Scattergood:  1878-1954
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; ScattergoodCOMMA Mary Cope EmlenCOMMA 1878-1975;
Subject: Bereavement; Death; Family
Notes: Letter of condolence upon the death of Jonathan Evans.
Transcript:
Awbury 1st Day 3/25/1911
[actually 26th]

My dear Algie

Mary & I felt it kindest not to intrude on you todayCOMMA being sure that you knew well how anxious we were to assist you at this sad time in anyway & that you would ask usCOMMA if we could do anything.

As I sit writing at the desk that thy dear father & cousin Rachel gave us as a wedding presentCOMMA many cherished memories of my associations with him & with you all come to me.

First of all I remember the pleasure of his first cordial greeting when I visited you at Conanicut for the first time. How heartily he & you all took me right into your familyCOMMA so that I have never since felt anyway not entirely at home in your house or enjoying your hospitality.Thy father was a revelation to me in his cheerfulnessCOMMA his joviality & his kindness to those about himCOMMA alwaysCOMMA it seemed to meCOMMA outdoing himself to give others pleasureCOMMA so oftenCOMMA tooCOMMA just young boys & girlsCOMMA some of whomCOMMA I fearCOMMA took a good deal of it for granted. His whole-hearted comradeship with his children & their friendsCOMMA without ever descending from the character of a true Christian gentlemanCOMMA has been of often & often an inspirtation to the and words cannot express what it has meant to me to be allowed by to share him so freelyCOMMA for there always seemed plenty of him to go around to everyone at his board or in his presence.

He & Cousin Rachel have been I have so often feltCOMMA much like a father & mother to me; I felt as free in talkingwith him as with my own fatherCOMMA & as sure of a sympathetic hearing. I shall never forget his wonderful kindness in coming up to Mt. Airy one evening at the time of Father's dearth & sitting with me & talking with the truest & most tender sympathy. It seemed too much for a man of his years to do for a young manCOMMA & yet nothing of the kind ever seemed too much for him appartently in his own eyes.

Just these few things & his love that they & other incidents like them have engendered in me have been pressing for expressions since I we all were so sadly shocked on 7th day morning by news of Cousin Jonathan's condition & I hope that He will not think it a miss in me to have given them expressionCOMMA for they have made me feel so close to him & to all of you that I have the most heartfelt sympathy for you all in this ordealso hard for you.

It is a great joy to me to have known thy father as I did & also to know [thear?] so many othersCOMMA allwho knew himCOMMA in factCOMMA say the same thing.

With sincere love & truly heart felt sympathy for thy dear Mother & Anna & thy brothersCOMMA I amCOMMA with love

Thy friendCOMMA
Alfred Scattergood

Title: 1900 April 22COMMA 2128 DelancyCOMMA to Francis & Anna Cope
Creator: Catharine M. Shipley:  1832-1922
Recipient: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916

2128 DeLancy
[1900]

My Dear Friends Francis & Anna CopeCOMMA First Thanks for the book. I'll look up this Jospeh John Gurney. He really was a quaker gentlemanCOMMA very nearly sound.T.P. Cope & I gave him the right hand of fellowship- Please keep well! Beacause I need youCOMMA it is a comfort to feel the presence of those whose nameless unremebered acts of kindness & of love adorne the doctrinesCOMMA Your Friend

Title: 1897 January 19COMMA OlneyCOMMA to Francis & Anna Cope
Creator: Samuel Morris:  1827-1905
Recipient: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1857-1897; ElliottCOMMA CharlotteCOMMA 1789-1871;
Subject: Bereavement in old age; Bible--N.T.; Death--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Poetry;
Notes:
Letter of condolence upon the death of Alfred CopeCOMMA Jr.
Includes Charlotte Elliott's poem "My GodCOMMA My FatherCOMMA While I Stray."
"Old Berkshire Mills 1895" watermark.
Transcript:
Olney 1 mo. 19. 97.

My dear friends
Francis & Anna CopeCOMMA

Those only who have passed thr'o a similar trialCOMMA can justly measure the affliction which is now your portion. So I find my heart going out in tender sympathy with yours and our earnest desire that he among whose gracious offices it still is to "heal the broken hearted"COMMA and "to comfort them that mourn"COMMA may be near to sustain & comfort you.

To a loving parentCOMMA the right time never comesCOMMA as viewed from our standpointCOMMA to part with a dear child. The infancyCOMMA its very tenderness & helplessness beget the care it is there so continually needing. As childhood comes with all its winsome waysCOMMA it is surely hard to give the little one up. And when mandhood or womanhood have been reachedCOMMA and ourhopes brighten for their futureCOMMA or we fondly look for ripenning fruit from all our care & anxiety & effort for their temporal & spiritual goodCOMMA a feeling akin to bitter disappointment is mingled with the sorrowCOMMA as we bear them to the silent tomb.

But the Christian believer has learnedCOMMA not only thr'o observing the lots of othersCOMMA but by his own happy experienceCOMMA that a Heavenly FatherCOMMA who "tender mercies are over all His works"COMMA and whose "compassions fail rest"COMMA knows best how to deal with us and our loved onesCOMMA and that "he doeth all things well". Whether we understand the meaning of the dispenesation or notCOMMA we can thr'o our tears exclaimCOMMA "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken awayCOMMA but blessed be the name of the Lord." This filial submission to the Will of GodCOMMA we well know comes to us only thr'o the humblingCOMMA sweeteningCOMMA calming influences of his grace. But I rejoice to believe you have known & felt its efficacious powerCOMMA and I long that it may in this time of needCOMMA rest largely upon the spirits of you both.Some sweet lines by Charlotte ElliotCOMMA you may be already familiar withCOMMA but they seem so fitted for those who are passing this heavy trialsCOMMA that I will add a few stanzasCOMMA th'o feeling sure you will appreciate them all.

If those shouldst call me to resign
What most I prizeCOMMA it ne'er was mine:
I only yield thee what was there;
"Thy will be done".

If but my fainting heart be blest
With thy sweet spirit for its guestCOMMA
My God! To thee I leave the restCOMMA
"Thy will be done"

Renew my will from day to day;
Blend it with thineCOMMA and take away
All that now makes it hard to sayCOMMA
"Thy will be done."

ThenCOMMA when on earth I breathe no more
The prayer half mixed with tears beforeCOMMA
We singCOMMA upon a happier shoreCOMMA
"Thy will be done"

My lameness still keeps me a crippleCOMMAand almost house-boundCOMMA or I should gladly have been with you ere thisCOMMA but the above may expressCOMMA better perhaps than I could in personCOMMA the loving sympathy and desires of

your attached friendCOMMA
Saml Morris.

Title: 1906 April 22COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Mrs. Evans
Creator: J. Henry (Joseph Henry) Scattergood:  1877-1953
Subject: Books;
Transcript:
4 mo 22 . '06

My dear Mrs. Evans

That was very sweet of thee to give me that most helpful little work of essays "Blessed be Drudgery." I have read "I had a friend"COMMA and enjoyed it exceedingly. How true it is that we must be found true last as well as first to hold real friendshipand dear love. How trueCOMMA tooCOMMA that down at bottom one must feel the repsect upon true love can grow into its highest. I like particularly those dying words of Brensen "as he looked up in the eyes of his wife bending over him 'In thy face I see the Eternal'." And also "in our best beloved"COMMA "we find as Emerson says " "our beautiful enemy" "our dear dread " "an outside conscience"COMMA spurring us to our best.

Anne says thee once readto her the essay "Blessed by Drudgery."
I am very much obliged for thy loving thought as well as the letter book itself. It is so good to feel thee & Mr. Evans as such very dear friends of both Anne & myself.

With sincere Thanks & loveCOMMA I am thy loving friend
J Henry Scattergood

Thanks dear AnnaCOMMA for thy many kind remembrances; the basket of flowers was exquisitely beautifulCOMMA how they remind us of the skill and benevolence of the great CreatorCOMMA cheer the path of life and touch the heart with gratitude to Him who has so bountifully provided for one enjoyment ever in his visible works.

With loveCOMMA
H. Rhoads

4th day 22nd.Anna S. Cope

Title: 1860 March 27COMMA Astor HouseCOMMA New YorkCOMMA to Thomas P. CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: John Stokes:  1800-1868
Identified People: StokesCOMMA Hannah SmithCOMMA 1799-1859;
Subject: Bereavement in old age; Children;
Transcript:
Thomas P. Cope Philada

My dear SonCOMMA I thought I could no longer forbear expressing in this way my feeble acknowledgements for thy many tokens of unparalleled kindness and generosity towards me and mineCOMMA the number and magnitude of which have frequently overwhelmed me with feelings that I cannot ever attempt to expressCOMMA and that simple gratitude is but a feeble term to represent. For since the departure of my beloved and sainted consortCOMMA whose loss I more and more deplore and which seems more and more irreparableCOMMA and almost constantly weighs upon my feelingsCOMMA there seems but few ties remaining to attach me to this worldCOMMA except my childrenCOMMA who seem to me (pardon a fathers weakness)COMMA so worthily to rifle at their mother’s virtues and gracesCOMMA that I hold myself excusable for wearing them in my hearts careCOMMA as constituting the principal charm of my declining years. So that amid all my trialsCOMMA and I have had my shareCOMMA I feel thankful that I am blessed with such a familyCOMMA and have been so favored in sundry waysCOMMA not the least of which is that of having in incorporated with usCOMMA oneCOMMA who seems to have been as a guardian angel to us all. And I am humbly sensible that I cannot be too thankful to a kind providence for such a blessingCOMMA and regard it as a special dispensation of divine mercy and goodness towards usCOMMA that thee has beenso cordially united to my familyCOMMA and that so much affectionate unity and sympathy should prevail amongst usCOMMA binding us together in bondsCOMMA which I trust nothing will ever be able to weaken or to sever. My dear departed consort and myself did frequently dwell upon these considerationsCOMMA and united in the belief that a blessing would attend thy influence and example on our childrenCOMMA particularly our sons; and I think this has indeed been already realized in good measure; and my sincere desire and prayer for them isCOMMA that they may continue to walk circumspectly and depend themselves wisely and consistently in all thingsCOMMA so as to render themselves in a degree worthy of thy almost paternal concern and kindness: which none of us can ever hope to compensate in any other way than by the most respectful deferenceCOMMA and affectionate regard; under a warm sense of whichCOMMA I concludeCOMMA and subscribe myself thy deeply obliged and grateful father in law.

John Stokes

Astor HouseCOMMA New York
3 Month 27thCOMMA 1860.

Title: 1840 July 31COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to AnnaCOMMA near Germantown
Creator: Hannah Sansom Vaux
Identified People: CressonCOMMA Charles CalebCOMMA 1816-1902; GurneyCOMMA Joseph JohnCOMMA 1788-1847; VauxCOMMA GeorgeCOMMA 1832-1915;
Unidentified People: grandfather; Sister Mary; Friend Paul; Harry Collins; Maria [Collins]; Sister Susan; Cousin S. Cresson; Brother Wm;
Subject: Death notices; Health; Prayer; Public worship--Society of Friends; Quakers--Anecdotes;
Geographic Subjects: Cape May (N.J.); Pennsylvania; Philadelphia (Pa.); Saratoga Springs (N.Y.);
Notes:
Account of visits by Joseph John GurneyCOMMA his departure from America.
RAMIES watermarkCOMMA profile of Benjamin Franklin emossing.
Transcript:
Philadelphia 7th mo 31st 1840.

My dearest AnnaCOMMA

When we last parted I had intended to fulfill my promise of writing to thee at a much earlier period than I have doneCOMMA but my time has been so much occupied that I have found it impossible to do soCOMMA and trust thee will not attribute it to forgetfulnessCOMMA as I can assure thee that although absentCOMMA thee is not forgotten. Several of the family have been very much indisposedCOMMA grandfather has indeed had quite a severe attackCOMMA we scarcely thought he would recover for a day or twoCOMMA but he is now very much improved and able to be about his room. The weather has been so very warmCOMMA I expect you enjoy the country exceedingly there are but a few persons now remaining in the cityCOMMA the streets are quite desertedCOMMA great numbers have gone to Cape May and other watering places. I understood from a gentleman who had just returned from Saratoga SpringsCOMMA that the Hotels there were very much crowdedCOMMA about four hundred visitors at one house.

I regretted exceedingly you were unable to hear Friend Gurney once more before his departureCOMMA I can scarcely realise that he has indeed left our native land foreverCOMMA as he now supposes; there was a little girl inquired of him if he would never return hereCOMMA and was almost broken heartedCOMMA when he placed his hand upon his head and repliedCOMMA that "his docks were too grey ever to expect to revisit this country". I had several op-portunities of being in company with him and they were much more delightful on account of being unexpected.

The First day morning before he left he attended the North MeetingCOMMA and gave us a very interesting and beautiful sermonCOMMA taking his text from the sixty third chapter of IsaiahCOMMA ninth Verse. After meeting Sister Mary and myself were returning homeCOMMA when Friend Paul joined us and saidCOMMA that she had fully expected we would have called to see Friend Gurney the evening beforeCOMMA that there was a number of friends and young people assembled at their houseCOMMA between sixty and seventy she thoughtCOMMA to bid him FarewellCOMMA and insisted upon our going home with her; as she said that it would be our last oppurtunityCOMMA we accordingly accepted her invitationCOMMA highly grateful as thee may suppose. Our particular facourite E. P. Kirkbride was there when we arrivedCOMMA and seveal other friends. Friend Gurney was very much pleased to see usCOMMA he said that he had been expecting usCOMMA and was very glad we had comeCOMMA he seated himself close by us and conversed awhile very sweetlyCOMMA after which we bade him adieuCOMMA wishing him a prosperous voyage and safe returnCOMMA he sent his Love to all the family a kiss to the younger ones. He had an appointed meeting at the Arch Street house in the evening. (I was very much surprised a few days after to hear that you had not attended it). It was very largeCOMMA he addressed us in a very interesting manner and furnished with a most touching prayerCOMMA in which he commended all his Endeared FriendsCOMMA to the protection of that SaviourCOMMA who had so long sheltered him under his parent wingCOMMA and had been with himCOMMA in joy and in sorrow in this land."

When the meeting had concludedCOMMA every one rushed to shake hands with himCOMMA I think he must have stood twenty minutesbidding all farewellCOMMA until I thought his hand really must ache however all were finally satisfiedCOMMA and we had just returned homeCOMMA when to our utter amazement who should arrive directly afterCOMMA but Joseph John he said he must see us all once moreCOMMA he sat a short time with usCOMMA and we then bade him adieuCOMMA although I trust it will not be forever. He sailed in "The Roseius" on the 25thCOMMA I shall be truly glad when I hear of his safe arrival at homeCOMMA for surely his children and relations must ardently desire to behold him againCOMMA if he makes such an impression upon strangers what must their feelings be? I shall leave the remainder to thy imagination; I have written a long narrative about him my Dear AnnaCOMMA supposing it would interest theeCOMMA if it does not thee must excuse the length of itCOMMA and not waste thy time in perusing it. I suppose thee has most probably heard of the death of Harry CollinsCOMMA and Maria’s loss of her dear little babeCOMMA his namesakeCOMMA so near the same timeCOMMA poor girl she must feel it very deeply. Sister Susan and family have gone into the country expecting to remain three weeks. Cousin S. Cresson is no anxiously awaiting the arrival of her son Charles &c they intended sailing on the 25th in the "Great Western" for New YorkCOMMA I suppose they will arrive here in a week or ten days.

Brother Wm is very anxious that some of us should take a trip through PennslyvaniaCOMMA we had thought of going to Cape May for the benefit of the bathing the Dr. having recommended it for GeorgeCOMMA but Mama was so unwilling that he should be near the seaCOMMA we have concluded that a mountain rideCOMMA will perhaps be equally beneficialCOMMA I do not think it likely we shall be absent longer than a week. My letter has become so very lengthyCOMMA that I have only room to add do write me a very long letter and very soonCOMMA give my love to all inquiring friends of course reserving a lrage portion for thyself and hoping this will find you all in a perfect state of salubrity believe mestill thy sincerely attached friend and cousin

Hannah S Vaux

P.S. Please excuse all blunders and do not allow any one to read this but thyself. (A speedy answer Dear Anna).

Title: 1876 November 20COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Clementine Cope. Connymead
Creator: George O. Walker:  b. 1838
Subject: Loneliness; Love; Love-letters; Marriage proposals; Poetry; Voyages and Travels
Transcript:
Woodbourne 11 mo. 20. 1876

My very Dear FriendCOMMA
Clementine CopeCOMMA

Wilt thou be So kindCOMMA as to go with me to FloridaCOMMA about the middle of January next? to that delightgul clime!

Where the Rose & Catalpa forever Shall bloomCOMMA
Where the chase cannot tireCOMMA nor the deer ever fail
Nor the mockingbird's musicCOMMA 'ere cease in the vale.

For the sake of enjoying thy pleasantCOMMA agreeable company I will pay all expenses there & back.
Have long thoughtCOMMA there was not another person in this WorldCOMMA I would prefer to Dear thee!
Long SinceCOMMA I was captivatedby thy winning ways agreeable manners & fine Sense! Thee was always so gentleCOMMA true & kind!
"Alive to every tender feelingCOMMA
To deeds of Mercy always noneCOMMA
The wounds of pain & sorrow healingCOMMA
With soft compassion sweetness to me.

No proud delayCOMMA no dark suspicionCOMMA
Taints the free bounty of her heartCOMMA
She turns not from the sad petitionCOMMA
But gentleCOMMA aid at once impart."

"To know theeCOMMA is to love thee!
Thou Knowest that I love thee."
"Love & love only is the loan for love.
Wilt thou not reciprocate my love?
& concent to unite thy destiny with mine?
It will always be my greatest de
-light to consult promote thy happiness
COMMA I do not approve of long engagementsCOMMA (does thee?)Our time in this world is tooCOMMA
Short to be long in forming its
Most happy connection.

I think our habitsCOMMA mannersCOMMA tastes dispoistion are similar & therefore congenial!

Whilst Dr. Norris his amiable WifeCOMMA SisterCOMMA Mother & Aunt were hereCOMMA they cheered my solitude very much by frequently inviting to dineCOMMA take tea &c. which I enjoyed.

Since their depeature for the CityCOMMA I feel quite lonely & the want of agreeableCOMMA cultivated female Society. Some Person that I can love & be kind toCOMMA as I have always loved Dear theeCOMMA in Sincerity & truth!

ThereforeCOMMA wilt thou not return my love & consent to marry me by Friends CerimonyCOMMA before going to Florida? Let that be thy Bridal tour? Please write me soon to allay myMy anxiety my suspense & say on what day next week it would be most convienient for thee to favor me with an interview at thy own comfortable home at Connymead & say also at what day & hour it will be convenient to send your carriage to me at your station.

Thanks to kind Providence I am now favored with good health & hope you all will long continue to enjoy the same blessing!

With Love to thy Sister & that love for Dear thee which neither time nor distance can efface.

Ever truly thy sincere & loving friend- Geo. Walker

Title: 1888 December 23COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Clementine Cope
Creator: George O. Walker:  b. 1838
Subject: Christmas; Gifts; Health; Loneliness; Weather;
Transcript:
Woodbourne 12/23- 88

My very Dear Friend Clementine CopeCOMMA Many thanks for your lovely Christmas Greeting & for Christmas Box ccontaining a superior Down Comfortable Superior Oranges grapes &c for which I am much obliged very grateful & much oblidged yesterday I tested the quality of the Down for keeping warm It was certainly very thoughtful & kind in sending a covering. So useful to protect from severe cold from the severity soften think of Elizabeth the exile of Siberia undertakiing a journey two thousand miles to obtain a pardon from the Emperor of Russia for her Father. When the weather is more congenial than at presentCOMMA I hope that you three lovely Sisters may not hesitate to perform a visit to yournative land where you will be certain to obtain a kind welcome we miss your agreeable manners & refined good sense more than words can tell. May we not anticipate the pleasure of a good long visit next summer three lovely sister. I sincerely wish you one & all a very Happy Christmas & New Year & Many happy returns of the Same. Thanks to a kind Providence I am still favored to enjoy good health with the exception of Rheumatism. I enjoy a good appetite & sleep will at nights for which I am very thankful. Please write soon to your deserted lonely friend & with that love which neither nor distance can efface for Dear thee Clementine I remain very truly & sincerely thy affectionate loving friend G Walker

Title: 1901 January 19COMMA to Father & Mother
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient: EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA Hannah BaconCOMMA 1839-1939
Unidentified People: Miss Richardson; Dr. Shine; Mr. Wells; Miss Barnard; Esther; Mr. Chipman; Miss Chapman
Subject: Flowers; Games; Mental illness; Skating; Sports; Weather; Weddings
Notes:
Letter written on January 19 & January 25COMMA 1901.
Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
[January 19th]
[1901]

Dearest Father & MotherCOMMA

First of all thank thee ever so muchCOMMA dear FatherCOMMA for the lovely flowers which came last evening. They are beautiful and the vase of carnations and asparagus fernCOMMA which Miss Richardson put on my center table this morningCOMMA was truly good to look at! I am glad youaccomplished the journey home comfortablyCOMMA and I hope Mother was not much the worse for all the exertion. I have been tobogganing since I saw you. Only once howeverCOMMA as the next time we tried it we found it was no good. We had a good rideCOMMA howeverCOMMA down to the hill hitched on behind the sleigh. I stay down in the evenings now till halfpast eightCOMMA and last night I laughed till my sides ached to see Dr. Shine and Mr Wells drilling Miss Barnard (one of the patients)- teaching her to salute etc. They were killing! They play a game here called LouisaCOMMA which is something like ParcheeseeCOMMA and we have fun on that too. I have progressedquite a little with the AutoharpCOMMA and find it quite absorbing-

[Jan. 25th]

Almost a week you see since this letter was startedCOMMA and I have a lot more things to acknowledge now. Two letters from MotherCOMMA I think (one of which I have just read. I don’t mean I haven't read both) besides one from EstherCOMMA and Frannie Strawbridge's weddinginvitation. The latter was indeed a surprise. I hope the man is nice. The silk dress also arrived safely & in good condition I think. Please give Esther my love and thank her for her letter which I was very glad to get. I dont think I thanked Alg or Ted for their last letters eitherCOMMA though they camea good while ago- Ted's especially. I certainly do get nice letters. I have been skating a good deal since I started this letter and having great fun playing hockey with Mr. Wells and Mr. Chipman and once with Miss Chapman (one of the nurses) & once with Miss Richardson. It soundsvery fine to say I played hockeyCOMMA but Miss Richardson and I could at least get our feet and skirts not to mention our sticks in front of the goal & so do some good. I shrieked so in the excitement I could be heard way up at the house!

I have finished the little hood I was knitting(which alas did not turn out to be a little one owing to my loose handling) & I have nearly finished another which is much more of a success. I guess I wont take another sheet but will begin to say good-by. Please give my dear love to each of the boysCOMMA & to them all at Grandpa's & Aunt Lilly's & [---] if you think of it. Tell Aunt Hannah I am using & enjoying her hunting bag. And with a lot of love for your own dear selves I am your loving little Daughter.

Title: 1901 JanuaryCOMMA to Family
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient: EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; FooteCOMMA Eleanor Tyson CopeCOMMA 1879-1973; ScattergoodCOMMA Mary Cope EmlenCOMMA 1878-1975
Unidentified People: Stedman family; Mary & Frank; Polly; Mr. Foote; Cousin Hannah; Esther; Miss Webb; Miss Richarson
Subject: Clothing and dress; Mental illness; Photographs; Quakers--Social life and customs; Telephone; Weddings
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Wednesday

[Jan ? 1901]

Dearest FamilyCOMMA

Well! I have had two visits since I last wroteCOMMA & mighty nice ones they were. Aunt L & Ellie came the first time (I told you I wondered which 2 it would beCOMMA didnt I?) & after theyhad been here about an hour & we had a good talk Dr. Stedman came up and said they would have time for a cup of tea at the [---] House (his house you know) & that Miss Stedman was there- Mrs. Stedman was away unfortunately. He asked me to come downCOMMA tooCOMMA so we all went& I enjoyed it ever so muchCOMMA as it was the first time I had been inside their house. I was sorry Aunt Lilly didn't see Mrs. StedmanCOMMA but I believe they have asked her & Miss Stedman to lunch with them at Brunswick so they will meet after all. I was in hopes the Doctor would let me go into lunch with them some day this week but he thinks I am not quite ready for thatCOMMA so they are coming out again. Mary & Frank came on Monday & we had a jolly timeCOMMA & Polly is coming out with Aunt Lilly & Ellie when they comeCOMMA I think. Frank will come againCOMMA toosometimeCOMMA I guess & I have found out that I can call him up on the telephone if I want to. I had a nice little talk with Polly last evening on that instrumentCOMMA & a few words with Aunt Lilly. The latter is not very fond of talking on it& they have had some rather funny times I guessCOMMA as they have telephones in their rooms to the office instead of bells. To-day they are Cambridge. I believeCOMMA lunching with Mr. Foote at the Colonial ClubCOMMA & are at present looking at the glass flowersCOMMA I expect. Of course youknow [---] or "tea" for themCOMMA & they met lots of people there. I told Dr. Stedman I was crazy to go to itCOMMA & he said he would love to let meCOMMA but he didnt think I was up to it. Perhaps I shall get to Class DayCOMMA however.

To change the subjectCOMMA I dont think I ever acknowledged the little bookthee mailed meCOMMA Mother dearCOMMA from Aunt Lizzie Cope. I [---] it all nightCOMMA & sometime will you give her my love & thank her very much for me? Then the photos & the card-case Aunt L brought. The card case is all right & so are the photosCOMMA but I'm going to bother you to send mesome more things. Thanks very much for these firstCOMMA however. The other things are- 1. the little lace tie to go around your neckCOMMA which Cousin Hannah sent me last summer- 2. my two lace collars- one of [---] edged with laceCOMMA & one of illusion with wide lace onthe edge- 3 my little gold pin (not a strap pin but a clasp) one of a pair I used to haveCOMMA & my little white wreath pin (that is if it is all right to send them by mail)COMMA 4 & some more photos. It is so nice to have those you sentCOMMA & I want more. I'd like my group of the GoldenWedding for one thingCOMMA & if there is a copy of that picture of Mother & me I want that & there is a picture of Esther in a little frame & one of Mary Emlen- & any others you can find. I cant have too many- If the frames are bulky dont send themCOMMA though I'd like to have the ones Esther & Mary are inCOMMAif you can manage it. If there are any old kodak pictures of Awbury or Conanicut send themCOMMA tooCOMMA but dont bother too much. You see it is so nice to have them to show to Miss Webb & other people to whom I talk about thingsCOMMA besides the phasum of having them to look at myself. I do wish therewas a good one of Father- You might send me the family group. He is pretty good in that. The one of the house you sent is great & I have it on my bureauCOMMA next to the boys.

Now I'm going to stop this scrawl. I hope you dont think I'veasked for a great many things. Miss Richardson thinks my bloomers are in my trunk. I'm awfully sorry. Miss R. wants to be remembered to Mother.

With lots of love I am in great haste.
Your very loving

Anna.

Title: 1901 September 4COMMA The HagueCOMMA to Mrs Jonathan EvansCOMMA Shropshire
Creator: Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Subject: Leisure; Netherlands--Description and travel; Voyages and Travels
Transcript:
Dear M. I am writing now from the Hague and am glad to say that I have found the others. Art came to the Hotel and waited for me & then we followed the others to the Hague. They had been in a pension and glad been on a trip to the Island of Marken. Of courseCOMMA it is perfectly great to see them. Hope you are all well. With love E.W.E. To-morrow we goto Delft & return here.BRIEFKAART

AAN Mrs Jonathan Evans
Hydropathic Hotel
Church Stretton
Shropshire
England.

Title: 1904 September 4COMMA ConanicutCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EmlenCOMMA Eleanor CopeCOMMA 1854-1920; EmlenCOMMA George WilliamsCOMMA 1853-1938; EmlenCOMMA SamuelCOMMA 1829-1920;
Unidentified People: Batemans; Whitalls; The Family Emlen; Art; Kimbers; Miss Simpson;
Subject: Family; Food habits; Leisure; Sailing; Voyages and Travels;
Transcript:
Conanicut
Sept 4th 1904

Dearest MotherCOMMA

Sunday and a large dinner having brought a temporary lull in the activities of our household I am going to get in a letter to thee before thee leaves Franconia.

With a jolly crowdCOMMA good weather and plenty to do we are enjoying ourselves very much and if only thee and Anna were here with us we could ask for little to make things complete. But since that may bot be we are rejoicing that we shallor at least some of usCOMMA see you before long at Batemans.

Since a week ago yesterday we have kept moving at quite a rapid gaitCOMMA leaving for the most part out of doors and hence cultivating large healthy appetites. Plates are busyCOMMA I can tell theeCOMMA passing up and down the "festive board"COMMA and as for the butter words fail. Of course our for us of entertainment are not so tremendously varied but they are good ones and hence we do not grow tired of repeating. We generally start out the day by playing some good active to properly shake our breakfast down and to put ourselves proper frame of mind for a swim and when this is attained we descend like "wolves on the fold" of those good friends of oursCOMMA the WhitallsCOMMA who in spite of our filling up their boat house and bath house still seem to preserve their equanimity of temper. For which let us be truly thankfulCOMMA for really I don't know how we could get along without our good swim off their pier.

Sailing is our principal other pastime and we have had several good times in the faithful "Three Sisters". HoweverCOMMA as we only hire the boat four days out of seven there are times when we must occupy ourselces in other ways. One of those days last we went on a picnic to Beaver Tail and had a splendid time the large express wagon up the Newport Transfer Co. sevred as our charist and pulled by four large horses kept in a gallop most of the way by our energetic driver we must I'm sure have made an imposing spectacle. The little cove where we usually go took on quite a homelike cozy air as it's walls reflected back the glow of our blazing bonfire round which we sat while some of the musical members entertained us. I think I enjoy our Beaver Tail picnics more than any others. Still whereI think of one we had only yesterday over on the mainland near where the boys once camped in narrow River I am tempted to qualify that statement.

The Family Emlen are qutie prevalent here this Sunday Sam and Art have come up over labor DayCOMMA Sam staying here and Art at the Kimbers while Cousins Ellie and George are just across the way from us. It is very nie to have so many friends here.

I am sorry that my long delay in writing has this time not even an excuse of verse but a mother's forbearance is so easily imposed onCOMMA that I hope thee will forgive me once more I am very glad thee liked the poem. By the wayCOMMA I never told thee that I would be very glad to hear what Miss Simpson has to say about my studying law.

With a great deal of love to ann and thyself.

Thy affectionate son
Edward

Title: 1906 June 26COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911;
Subject: Flowers; Transportation; Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Conanicut (Island : R.I.); Jersey City (N.J.); Lehigh River Valley (Pa.); New York (N.Y.); Tunkhannock (Pa.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.);
Transcript:
Woodbourne
June 26th 1906

Dearest MotherCOMMA

My postal from New York will have informed you that the first part of my journey was safely accomplished and you will be glad to know that the ending was also successful. After fooling around in the Natural History Museum till about eleven o'clock I went down town again via the subway and boarded the Black Diamond in Jersey City. It was a fine day and very pretty coming up. The trip on the little train from Tunkhannock to Woodbourne was especially pretty. Many of the fields were a mass of white and yellow with daisies and buttercups and the soft late afternoon sunlight still brightness the hillsides. I arrived at Woodbourne just about ontimeCOMMA that isCOMMA 7 o'clock and Frank and Er drove down to meet me. They are all well and happy apparentlyCOMMA disquieted only by the fact that Theadora has a habit of yelling like a trooper where put to bed. Tell Father and Miss Richardson that I placed two kissesCOMMA one on each check for the respective ones which they sent. She didn't burst into tears as you mighthave expected but only weathered me with a stony stare.

Last night was beautifully dear and today is bright. I hope the fog has been blown away from Conanicut. Aunt Lilly seeds her love and says to thank thee very much for thy letter; she will write soon. Please give my love to Father and Anna and tell the former that the mileage book was not good on the Lehigh Valley.

Affectionately thy son
Edward

Title: 1911 July 16COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Aunt Lilly
Creator: Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939;
Subject: Death--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Family;
Notes: Thanking for letter of sympathy after death of Ernest Mervyn Evans.
Transcript:
Woodbourne
SundayCOMMA July 16COMMA 1911

Dear Aunt LillyCOMMA

I want to thank thee veryCOMMA very much for thy letter to meCOMMA so full of love and sympathy and helpful thought for Jack and me and for us all. Thee knowsCOMMA I am sureCOMMA how glad we all are of the assurance that the miles which separate us cannot prevent theCOMMA being with us in spiritCOMMA nor us with thee. I am sure this experience of sudden and great sorrow has given us allCOMMA (and manyCOMMA alsoCOMMA I thinkCOMMA outside our family circles)COMMA a new vision of the sacredness and beauty of these lives of ours however commonplace their daily rounds may seem and to meCOMMA I thinkCOMMA the greatest inspiration of all comes from the thought of how dear Ern's spirit by the darkCOMMA faithfulness of his unselfishnessCOMMA which all who knew him feltCOMMA was unconsciouslygrowing to that wonderful capacity for selflessness which he so beautifully displayed in those last hours. I know he would be the last one to wish praise that was not due or ever praise at all but he would rejoice for us all together from this experience and to go forward with more and more steadfast faithfulness to the light that is given us.

It is lovely being up here all together in the quiet peace of the woods and hills with Frank and Ev and I wish we had theeCOMMA too. Woodbourne is almost like another home to me.

HaroldCOMMA I am sorry to sayCOMMA had to leave us todayCOMMA but he went I am sure much the better for his eight days here and enjoyed it all very much. You are all very good to take us in so generously.

I have read Jack's note and see that she has mentioned that this is Ernest's Birthday. I think we all feel much as she says about his appreciation of Woodbourne and love of nature.

Mother and Anna seem wonderfully wellCOMMA I thinkCOMMA and it has been very good for AlgCOMMA too. The weather is very pleasantCOMMA a delightful breeze keeping the hilltop cool and fresh today.

Alg is the only other member of the family about us now and he sends a great deal of love to thee and to you all. I join warmly in his message with a special one of love to Ell. And please tell her how much her letter meant to us all. How I wish she were here with us now!

We were very sorry to hear of Uncle Tom's loss on the way up. We didCOMMA indeed appreciate having him with us at Awbury and all he did for us.

Thy very affectionate nephew
Edward.

Title: 1905 June 17COMMA S.S. MinnehahaCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Ernest Mervyn Evans:  1884-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976;FooteCOMMA Eleanor Tyson CopeCOMMA 1879-1973;  LewisCOMMA William DraperCOMMA 1867-1949;
Unidentified People: Argill and O'Brien; Mr Tucker; George;
Subject: Haverford College; Sailing; Transportation; Voyages and Travels;
Transcript:
Please return!

[mailed NYC 6/17/1905]

Dear MotherCOMMA

Here we are safe and sound on board the old craft and out of sight of land already at 7.30 a.m. I am writing this to go by the pilot as he has not left us yet. The main reason for our being out of sight of land is that the fog is ratherthick. I didn't turn out very early and am just as glad that I didn't as there wasn't much to be seen I guessCOMMA coming down the harbor. Ed didn't eitherCOMMA though he had thought of it last night. Our roommates are named Argill and O'Brien. The latter appears to be a self-made IrishmanCOMMA but rather good company I guess. Argill I have not seen yet in his civilized clothes. He is not what youwould call a sleeping beauty. George says he has a very nice man in his room. A Mr Tucker.

Class Day and commencement went off very well and we had very good weather a very seemtial point. Uncle Will made nice address.

Please thank Anna very much for her steamer letter. It was very good of her to write. Please give my love and Aunty Lily and Ellie. Ed sends love to them and to both Ann & thyself in which I join.

Lovingly thy sonCOMMA
Ernest

June 17. 1905
P.S. I forgot to thank thee for thy steamer letter tooCOMMA dear.

Title: 1905 August 16COMMA Hotel de Rome & SuisseCOMMA VeniseCOMMA to Grandpa
Creator: Ernest Mervyn Evans:  1884-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; LewisCOMMA William DraperCOMMA 1867-1949; TitianCOMMA ca. 1488-1576;
Subject: ArtCOMMA Renaissance--Italy; Grand Canal (VeniceCOMMA Italy); Italy--Description and Travel; Piazza San Marco (VeniceCOMMA Italy); Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Desenzano del Garda (Italy); MaggioreCOMMA Lake (Italy and Switzerland); Milan (Italy); New York (N.Y.); Switzerland; Venice (Italy);
Transcript:
Dear GrandpaCOMMA

As mother in her last letter makes some mention of forwarding letters to you at North East I am going to try to give thee a little direct news instead of such second hand stuff. We are; as this large poster at the top of the page is intended to indicateCOMMA I supposeCOMMA staying at this Hotel de Rome in Venice. Hotel de New York would be a more apporopriate title as the house is full of Americans.

Venice is certainly a most picturesque and interesting place and would be a most attractive place for a long stay if it were not for the Italians and the smells. However in this last respect it is nothing to DesenzanoCOMMA which has certainly pleanty of "loacl atmosphere" about it. We arrived in Venice on Fifth day (8/24) and since then have been trying to see something of the sights of the old city. It was certainly a most complete change to embark on a gondola and be rowedCOMMA paddledCOMMA or whatever they call itCOMMA to our hotel. It seemed as though we were living in a picture. Fortunality our hotel is on the grand Canal and only about five minutes walk from the square of St. Marks. We have spent quite a good deal of our time about the last and have enjoyed the fine old church much. The more one seens of it the more you begin to appreciate it. The mosaics are wonderful and the whole effect of the interior of the church (though somewhat interfered with by scaffoldingCOMMA just now) is one of great richness of color. I think though that at least as far as architecture is concerned I prefer some of the fine onld English ministers. the Doges Place is also very fine in many ways but not nearly so attractive as St. Mark. The ceiling decorations are too heavyand intricate for my taste. We spent about two hours of one afternoon in a gondola on the Grand CanalCOMMA a most lazy but throughly enjoyable way of spending our time. Thee old canals areCOMMA I thinkCOMMA decidely the most attractive part of the placeCOMMA and the gondola seems to fit them admirably. We want from one side to the other of the Grand Canal and were finally landed on our own doorstep. A most easy and satisfactory performance.

An emormous Italian (or French (?)) gentleman who is staying at our hotel is probably not so enthusiastic on this last subject as he managed to fall overboard during the performance to-day. Edward and I were aroused from the writing room by a great screaming of women and ran out on the porch expecting that something serious had happenedCOMMA only to fin this great lump sitting on the stepsCOMMA wet up to waistCOMMA and looking like some old sealion. He was so mad that he raged about in true Italian style and for some time refused to pay his gondoleerCOMMA or "poppe" I believe they call the man who runs the craft. It was really very amusing.

This morning we went to the picture Gallery here. The colors of some of the old masterpieces are very fine but I am afraid that I am not educated up to an appreciation of them. The faces are so impassive that it quite destroys the sentiment and feeling in the work. Uncle Tom I suppose will laugh at thisCOMMA but I can't help it. They are impassive. Titian's "Assumption of the Madonna" was thr finest work we saw there I think. The coloring and grouping in it are fine.

To-morrow we leave for Milan and thence on Second day we expect to go up into Switzerland again by way of Lago Maggiore. It will be quite a relief in some waysCOMMA for I don't care for the Italian people or their smells. Please give Uncles Tom & Will and Aunt Carrie my love. Also please give a great deal of love to Grandma. Ed sends his love to thee and Grandma. With much love from thy affectionate Grandson Ernest.

Title: 1902 August 7COMMA JamestownCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Ernest Mervyn Evans:  1884-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; EmlenCOMMA Arthur CopeCOMMA 1882-1941; EmlenCOMMA SamuelCOMMA 1829-1920; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; ScattergoodCOMMA Mary Cope EmlenCOMMA 1878-1975; StokesCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1833-1917; StokesCOMMA Katharine Wistar EvansCOMMA 1841-1904
Unidentified People: Mildred; Greta; Bessie Norris; Mrs. Whitall; Mrs Kimber; Natalie; Mary Jones
Subject: Bicycle touring; Birds; Camping; Hiking; Leisure
Geographic Subjects: Mississippi River; Newport (R.I.); Wood River Junction (R.I.); Wissahickon Creek (Pa.)
Transcript:
Jamestown
Aug 7th 1902

Dear Mother

Thy material "kick" having landed upon a tolerably tender spot I will try and mind my ways for the once. This morning Ed had to go to the dentist's to get his nerve killed or rather to have the dead nerve fixed; he has been pretty luckjy as he hasn't suffured hardly at all with it since he went to thy dentist nearly three weeks. FatherCOMMA Uncle Frank and Harold want up to tho Golf Club and played two rounds and Sam and I went over to Whitall's and had a swim. MildredCOMMA Greta & Mrs. Whitall are over at Nantucket where they want the early part of tho week (2nd day with Bessie Norris and Mrs Kimber and Natalie. They are expecting to return this afternoon or eveninig I believe as father wrote to thee Ed and I went upon a voyage of exploration on last fifth day. We started on the the 7.50 Beaverstail for Sanderstown and thence we rode our bicycles (hired ours from Newport) up to Nickford Junction. The roads back of Sanderstown and pretty fierce for riding but after we reached HamiltonCOMMA a village about 3 miles upCOMMA we had good roads the rest of the 8 miles to Nickford Junction. I know we took the train down to Wood River Junction and there again took to our wheels and rode about 8 miles on up to Barbervillea little [nibling] village. We left our bicycles there and started to tramp up the Wood River on which we wanted to camp. We found that the river was well wooded and that the backs were steep and suitableCOMMA where not too steepCOMMA for camping. But the river sitself was a great disappointment to meCOMMA & I guess to Ed too; the channel was far too wide & shallow and the current was slowCOMMA and in consequence for some distance out from the bank the river was full of reeds & lily pads. I should tell thee tooCOMMA in order that thee may not think that we were exploring a second MississippiCOMMA that "the river" is not larger than the Wissahickon. We tramped up stream for about a mile and there ate dinnerCOMMA which was dry (hard boiled eggsCOMMA bread & butter sandwiches and chickens) and we had not water and were pretty thirsty. Not much satisfcation in that. Then we walked about half a mile on up stream and then the river broadened out into a marshy place where it received quite a large tributary in the shape of a creek which comes down from above Arcadia. We couldn't find the place and tramped by the creekCOMMA there failing to find it we though that the creek must be the river and came back and explored that for a ways only to find our mistake and once more we start out to tramparound in quest of the river. Now it is a little difficult to set out through a country where you are a perfect stranger to find a river which seems determined to loose itself in a marsh; and the difficulties are not much lightened by the country being full of little ridges which run up very steep to about 30 or 40 ft and then stide off on the other side without stopping to make any flat top. Well the outcome of it was that we gave it up and bring pretty well wearied by our exertions and also extremely thristy we returned to the creek & had a swim; then returned got our wheels and rode to Hope Valley where we each drank a bottle of root beer (quite nonintoxicating) and got a plain soda to help quench our thirst and;returned to Wood River Junction by the train. In the midst of the trip it will doubtless thrill thy mothers heart with pride to know that the seat of my trousers had given way and that our hands and faces had more dirt on them that was seemlyCOMMA and for part of the way we looked like the convincing biker with a "gutta percha" faceCOMMA as Ed put it. There we rode a cross from Kingston in a wild hope of catching the six thirty boat from Sanderstown and in the midst of the way (its between 8 & 10 miles) and we had 55 minutes to do and my chain broke as I was riding down a hill. We missed the boat. After we had reached Sanderstown by a system of coasting down hillsCOMMA walkingCOMMA and in some favorable places bringtowed by EdCOMMA we took the 7.45 boat and again reached our "happy home" without having found a camping spotCOMMA but with a better knowledge of the country and so forth; so it was not all in vain. Well now I will try to give the a little more general newsCOMMA and not fill the whole letter with Wood River. We are expecting AlgCOMMA Art & Mary Emlem & Mary Jones on here on First day morning; it will certainly be great to see there all so soon. Tell Anna that we have been keeping a watch on some Vesper Sparrow's rest down here now Sam and ICOMMA chiefly SamCOMMA are studying a Grasshopper Sparrows nest. This very likely won't interest her very especially so there need not tell it unless thee feels like it; I thought it might on account of your [Vircos'] nest. The lady with the name will be able to tell you what Grasshopper & Vesper sparrows are like if you don't know. I suppose thee knows that "teacher Helma" Sutton is staying down at the Bay Voyage and at present Mr & Mrs. Haines & the two girls are staing there also Mrs. Alexander Wood and her sister Hannah Stokes are living there but are expecting to go home next week. Well as it is getting on toward ten o'clock and as the news seems pretty well run out I guess I will close with a great deal of love for both them and Anna.

from thy Affectionate son
Ernest

P.S. Uncle FrankCOMMA Aunt Kate and Ed all send a great deal of love (Harold has gone to bed) to both Anna & thee.

Subject: Camping; Hiking; Landscape; Leisure; New England--Description and Travel
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Conanicut (Island : R.I.); Ten Mile River (Mass.)
Transcript:
[1904]

Jamestown
Aug 14th

Dear Mother
I was very glad to get thy letter - and am sorry I have not written more frequently of late. I am also sorry that thee missed thy sleep even though it was for the benefit of thy son. I hope thee don't wake up at such times usually.

We returned from [---] on Sixth day afternoon. There were two crowds at the Lodge at different times- and so Margaret asked me to stay over I had a fine long visit from Monday morning until Friday noon. KatharineCOMMA MildredCOMMA & Marianna Buffum and Mary Reamy (a school friend of Margaret's) went over on the 6.15 trip of the Conanicut with Harold and meCOMMA and arrived at the LodgeCOMMA via. MickfordCOMMA at about two o'clock Margaret and George drove down and Mr Buffum and Billy rode on horse back. We welcomed them to the Lodge about twelveCOMMA Mrs BuffumCope and GeorgeCOMMA the coachmanCOMMA arrived about four. Thus the first crowd migrated in small flocks. Miss Blodgett came on Third day afternoon. She is an East Greenwich girl and seems very nice and jolly though I dont know her very well -as I had never set eyes on her before she came to camp. She stayed until FridayCOMMA but Katharine Mildred & Miss Reamy came up on Fourth day afternoon with Harold & GeorgeCOMMA so I was left a stranger among strangers. The others who came late Tuesday night & on Wednesday morning were Mary Sands & Frida Paine (both Newporters) [---] Spencer and Geo. PhillipsCOMMA the last being a Boston fellow. Now I believe I have catalogued the crowd. Thee knows that the Lodge is right on the Qiocompang PondCOMMA a lake a little over a mile long and a little over half a mile wide. The shores are quite irregular and are wooded right down to the very brinkCOMMA the underbrush overhanging the water in many placesCOMMA so the lakeCOMMA though small is very pretty. If you paddle to the far end of the lake from the Lodgeand then push up into a little reedy cove and make a carry of about 30 or 40 yardsCOMMA you find yourself in [---] Pond- a small pond quite different in character from Qiocompang- as the shores are steep and there is a narrow stoney beach all around. If you paddle to the far end of [---] Pond and then land and climb the hill through woods you can look out across the country and see the ocean beyond. Which is a pretty nice thing to do. I went down twice once with Katharine and again with Miss Blodgett.We had some good walks too. The woods are pretty around that section and the whole country is surprisingly wild and unspoiled. There are deer and grouse in fairly good numbers and they say that there are trout in the streams and bass and pickerel & pirch in the lake. There are a good many nice wood trails to walk along and it is great sport exploring and seeing where you bring up. You have to be careful though as you can lose yourself without much difficulty. We had a great walk on Fourth day morning in a pouring rain. Most ofthe way over (we went to Natchang Pond a lake about five miles from the Lodge by the way we went over) was through the woods for most of the way and through little trails. I was piloting the party over and as I had only taken the walk once and that was two years ago I was a little nervous but by good luck turned out O.K. Harold had been over this way with us the time before and Mr Buffum knew the general lay of the land pretty well so it wasn't so bad as it sounds. It rained like everything and we simply drenched but had great sport. Some of the girls went in bathing suits.

So much for [---]. I'll try to get down & things nearer home. If it suits you I am thinking of coming up to see you for a few days. As I have just been away and as there are great attractions here in the shape of a prospective canoeing party on the Ten Mile River and Henry Scattergood and possibly Frank Stokes on Seventh and First dayCOMMA I think that I wont come up until to-morrow week Aug 22nd and stay until Sixth day the 26th. If this don't suit you I hope you will let me know. I feel as if I had been off on a great many side trips since this summer and don't feel as if I ought to be the one to go again. It seems as though the other boys ought to have a turn. But it looks now as though I were going to be this forward one again. So I am looking forward to seeing you on the 22nd if all goes well. It will be fine.

Esther arrived yesterday and Elizabeth Roberts is staying with us too and as Stodgell Stokes took dinner with us we are quite gay. Yesterday afternoon Katharine and I walked down to Beaver tail. It was very nice down there as usual tho. there was no surf. We sat on the rocks for a while and got back just about seven. The rest of them took a drive except Harold who played tennis with Margaret Buffum at the club. Esther Emlen is staying at the Emlens. She wanted me to send her love to thee and A. Please give the latter much love and keep much for thyself.
As ever thy affectionate son

Ernest P.S. I think I will come up on the train leaving Boston at 10.00 & arriving at Littleton at 4.30 If Littleton is not the sta. please let me know. Esther & Ed send love.

Title: 1901 March 13COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
