(Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976;  EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; FooteCOMMA Eleanor Tyson CopeCOMMA 1879-1973; ScattergoodCOMMA J. Henry (Joseph Henry)COMMA 1877-1953
Unidentified People: Mary; Esther; Whitalls; Greta; Jay Brown; Billy Kimber; Annie Day; Morris Bockins
Subject: Coins; Family
Notes: Embossed heading of Girard Trust CompanyCOMMA Broad & Chestnut StreetsCOMMA Philadelphia.
Transcript:
March 13th 1901

Dear Mother-
As things are very slack in here today I think it will be a good chance to write thee even tho I think there is almost nothing new to be told. Last night Aunt Lilly & the girls turned up all right. Father & I went over to see Aunt Lilly & Ellie in the evening and they seemed to have stood the journey very well. We have been having a great time arranging about the Shakespeare Class. When we received on 2nd day a letter from Aunt Lilly saying that it was very doubtful if they could get parlor car seats for 3rd day and that unless they could certainly have three seats before they started they would not come up until 4th day as Mary & Ellie very likely would be too tired to come; and when at the Tea meeting Esther said she did not feel like coming we became very much more doubtful about the wisdom of trying to have the class In fact father was so discouraged that he said he didnt "care whether it ever met or not" and that I could so as I pleased so I decided to put it off a week to let the Hackers and Annie Day know about our change of plans which I did with apologies. Then last night when we found that Mary & Ellie would be able to come we again had misgivingsCOMMA so over we trotted to Ls. Ellie encouraged us to have it this week at their houseCOMMA as Harold having the measles might scare some of them from comingCOMMA so once again we wrote to the Hackers & A. de P. telling them of the final arrangement. I am almost afraid now to see them!!! Aunt Lilly has enjoyed her trip immensely and it has done her a lot of good I have no doubt. She certainly looks very well & is full of [---] while away.

As father no doubt has told thee we went down to the Tea meetingon 2nd day & had a very nice time. I enjoyed it very much tho the room was very hot & stuffy in the evening when the papers were being read so that I was very sleepy & could notCOMMA I am afraidCOMMA pay very strict attention to all that was being said. Still I got something out of it & enjoyed the tea very much. On 6th day 2

evening Ed & I went over to a small party at the Whitalls. Greta had home Marion Lane who is in her class and had asked Letitia Wright the EmlensCOMMA Jay Brown & Billy Kimber to come over. We had a very nice time tho nothing at all thrilling. On our way over I picked up a $10 gold piece on Church Lane in front of the Storks! I have never had any luck that way before & could hardly believe my eyes. I looked for any advertisements for it but could find none. On 1st day I enquired I enquired of them at Church Lane but none of them had lost any money. I asked Henry if Morris Bockins had lost anything as I thought he might carry some gold but Henry had not heard of him losing anything. In the afternoon therefore Ed & I started over to Boltons to advertise the Ledger but left doing it on our way over as the boy at Boltons said it did not have to be sent before 5.30 to get in 2nd days paper. When we got over to the Stokes Henry announced that the owner of my $10 was a poor woman in Irishtown. I thought he was only kidding but he said that he had seen Morris Bockins after meeting & had asked him whether he had lost any money. Mr B. said that he had not lost any directly but a poor boy who was coming over to his house from Irishtown with the [---]COMMA had been unable to curb his curiosity to look at the money which his mother had given him & his looking at it had dropped a $10 gold piece which he had search diligently for but had been unable to find where upon he was so much over came that he had run home at once. The next morning his mother had come over & told how her son had lost the money & that her husband had looked for it very early the next morning but had been unable to find it & that consequently she could pay her rent. The poor woman he said was very much broken up about her loss. As these facts entirely agreed with what I knew3

about the $10 there was no doubt but that the woman was the owner of the moneyCOMMA which is very satisfactory as there would probably have been a good many people who would have flocked to me if I had advertised and it might have been hard to tell who really did own it. I am certain now that the right person got the money & am very glad that she has it! Well I have written a great deal about this coin but there thee knows the likes details in letters thee says! On 7th day our bowling club met & we had a very good time. I enjoyed it especially as I bowled the highest score I have made this year. Harold seems to be coming on slowly. I am expecting very likely to get the disease as no one seems to be very careful about keeping the doors shut but I guess it wouldnt make much difference. It dont hardly seem worth while however to go over to grandpas as I think I have been exposed to it already. Still we'll see what the doctor says. I am very glad thee is enjoying thyself in a great way & hope it is doing thee a great deal of good. Aunt lilly & Ellie talked to Anna over the phone just before they started (perhaps it was 2nd day night) & she sent her love to us all.

I am thy loving son
Algernon

(Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; StokesCOMMA Francis JosephCOMMA 1873-1955; StokesCOMMA Stodgell

Subject: Cricket matches; Dogs; Family; Fourth of July celebrations; Weather
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Jamestown (R.I.); Moorestown (N.J.); Villanova (Pa.); Willow Grove (Pa.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.)
Transcript:
Awbury 7/8/01

Dearest Mother
It seems rather absurd to start to write to you so soon after you started but by my calculations it will have to be written tonight in order to catch you on your arrival as I will not be able to [---] tomorrow night and this must go by 4th days boat. I suppose that as you will have fully recovered from any bad effects of the voyage when this reaches you it will be ok for my to express my present wonderings about your present condition. I hope that you are not wishing like Ellie Garrett did that you were like a woman in Boston who hadnt any stomach. I dont believe you are tho it is not so very long since you started and I am afraid that there is a chance that in spite of all opinion plaster;s etc the sea may still have its effects on certain onesCOMMA I wont mention names! Well we are having not delightfully cool weather now. It is simply great here at home but I can just hear those at Woodbourne and at Jamestown comment on their blessings in having it so cool and sigh for those of us who have to stay ay [---] in "that awful heat." Well poor things it makes them feel a sight happier and it dont hurt us. We have just had a circus of a time with a couple of fox terrier pups wich uncle Hazen invited in. He has been keeping them down at the stable during his absense and Uncle Thomas' household have had a perfectly charming time with their midnight serenades. Tonight he came home & brought them down here and they didnt do a thing but get themselves and every body else tied up and during supper time they raised perfect cane barking. UncleHazen had to rush out a couple times to see the cause of the rumpus and now he has put them down in the cellar and because they are quiet now thinks he has solved the problem of keeping them quiet! I have my doubts but am not saying anything just yet a while. Grandpa and Uncle T. did not come down today after all. Uncle Hazen received a telegram today saying that they would be down on 4th day. I rather expect that Uncle Hazens stage party which comes off tomorrow night has rather discouraged them tho I dont know anything about it. I did nothing during thr 4th except go over to Ros[---] in the evening and see them send off a lot of fireworks which were very good considering they were private. The Goodhue kids were great sports. Little [---] nearly turned inside out when a rocket or bomb went off. On 7th day I took a Sabbath day journey out to Moorestown and played cricket which turned out desasterously to us as we were beaten 162 to 50 of which I made 10. I stayed out at Moorestown with Stodgell Stokes to supper and had a very pleasant visit with them. I had never been there before and enjoyed seeing them much. Dr & Mrs Stokes inquired after you all. I had intended to get out to Joes Morris' to stay over 1st day but I could not get in town in time to get out to Villa Nova before very late so I came home. On 1st day I went to Frank Goodhues to dinner and in the evening went to Emlens to supper. On 6th day Evening I went down to Shoemakers to see Anna & Frank Fortunately they were at home and I had a very nice visit. Tomorrow Anna HackerCOMMA Mary JonesCOMMA Annie WilliamsCOMMA Frank StokesCOMMA Frank Strawbridge & myself are going up to Willow Grove. I guess we will have pretty good time. Tell Ed that I tried to getsomething for ASM but all the stores were closed before I got there at the Girard namely [---]. I will try & do it tomorrow. I have not heard anything definite about my vacation yet but I guess I can have it sometime in Aug. I am fine & well so dont be [---] of those who bother about the heat. Give my love to Anna Ed Es. and with a great deal for thyself I am as ever thy loving son Alg.

Subject: Death; Death notices; Health; Pneumonia
Notes: Informs of the death of Elizabeth Waln Cope.
Transcript:
Girard Trust Co
7/30/02

Dear Mother
My letters do not seem to have any regular time for going to thee this summer and I cant remember when I last wrote but this is to tell thee about Aunt Lizzie Cope. Thee probably has heard that she was not so well lately and on 2nd day Grandpa and uncle Tom went down for the day to Ventnor to see her. They found that she wasCOMMA as they had expectedCOMMA much worse than when she left Awbury tho she was very glad to see them. She had a great deal of 2

trouble breathing. Yesterday morning they up at uncle Thomas received a telegram from down there saying that she was worse and later on in the morning another one came saying that she had pneumonia which of course made them fear the worst. Late in the afternoon another message came that she had quietly passed away at about 4 oclock in the afternoon. Cousin MadgieCOMMA Ellie & John were all down there at the time and cousin Harry & Walter went down in the afternoon. I did not know anything about it until late last night when I came home from the Harris (Joes) where a lot of us were at a porch party so that I did not get a 3

Chance to write until this morning. GrandpaCOMMA uncle Tom also had very little time to write as Cousin Eliza came over to supper (as cousin Walter had gone down) and Ridlgley Brown had also been asked to supper. I do not know any thing further as of course we have not heard anything more. I dont know when the funeral will be.

As I said before she had been much weaker lately and her heart not been as strong so that they were very much concerned about her tho the Dr did not give up hope as she said you could not tell in heart cases how long a person might live. When Grandpa was down on 2nd day they did not know that she had pneumonia tho she was much worse than she had been. She was up 4

when they saw her. She had a bad night and in the morning the Dr said she had pneumonia and did not look for her to recover. I do not know how she took cold.

I have been having a great deal going on in a special way lately so that I have not had a chance to do all the things I have wanted to doCOMMA- one of which was to may Joe Morris a visit. Alf & Henry are out there now but Joe & Ev go up to Woodbourne [---] about the 1st. I have not time to write more at present. Things certainly have kept moving this summer & I have had a mighty good time. We are all very well. Please give my love to AnnaCOMMA with lots for thyself I am as ever thine
Algernon

Title: 1905 July 9COMMA Boyer stCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA CadwalladerCOMMA 1762-1841; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; MorrisCOMMA Joe (Joseph Paul)COMMA 1879-1919; StokesCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1833-1917; StokesCOMMA Katharine Wistar EvansCOMMA 1841-1904;
Unidentified People: Alf; Mary; Jos Evans; Owen Evans; Jack Hollingsworth; Henry Pleasants; Mr Jackson; Mary; John;
Subject: Boardinghouses; Genealogy; Hicksites; Marriage proposals; Summer;
Notes: Forefather mentioned likely a reference to Thomas ap Evan (1651-1738)
Transcript:
Boyer st
7/9/05

Dear Mother
I have been very poor about writing to thee but last First Day I wrote a long letter to Ed. which took all of the time I had for writing so thee and father were neglected. It is lovely to think of thy being at Jamestown and I only wish I was there too to be with you:- Not that I am not having a very good time here at home; for I am. It seems to me that every summer almost is nicer than the last. Of course this one is still very young and it may be that I will whistle another tune before it grows old. I am having a very nice time indeed with Alf while Mary is away. Today we went off for an all day jaunt. we started at about quarter of nine to drive up to GwyneddCOMMA planning to go to meeting at the old Hicksite meeting opposite the William Penn Hotel. We thought meeting started at about 10.30 so that we did not feel very badlyCOMMA as we had come so farCOMMA at arriving at 10.45. After taking ourseats and hearing the end of a sermon we were surprised and disappointed to see the friends shake hands immidiately. We found that 10 oclock was the hour and we therefore only had about 5 minutes of it! After meeting we had a pleasant talk with Jos Evans who lives in Owen Evans old house which is the house father and I visited and where our forefather lived. He kindly asked us to come and take dinner with him but as he said that they had a good many boarders and he guessed that they could "Get around to us all night" we decided that itwas probably not very convenient to them and we therefore declined. We then wandered along the road towards where Cadwalader Evans lived which is now owned by the HollingsworthsCOMMA and lay down under a tree in the shade to take life easy as it was a pretty hot day. Pretty soon who should come along but Jack Hollingsworth and his sister coming down from church. Whereupon he asked us to come home with them and take dinner which we were very glad to do. Jack Hollingsworth also works at the Girard so I knowhim quite well. He is a very nice fellow. We found Henry Pleasants also there but Mrs Hollingsworth was out. The house is extremely attractive inside as well as out and I was very glad to see it. After a very good dinner and a very pleasant time we drove back to Uncle Franks where we found only Uncle F. & Aunt K. We took supper with them and had a very nice time.

Yesterday we went canoeing on the Rancocas and had a very good time. Frank Evelyn Joe & Jack & I were the crowd and we took two canoes. It was a very hot day but on the stream it was very pleasant. The gentlemen of the party managed to get a swim while the ladies went wading. We then cooked a very good supper for ourselves and every body agreed- even Frank who lost a six dollar pair of eyeglasses in the stream!- that we had a very successful day.

I have not yet found out definitely when I can have my vacation but I can not go before Mr Jackson returns which will be about the 12th of Aug. In fact I could not run off right away then I think and I therefore can not come up to Jamestown before the 19th but I hope to be able to get off then or a week later. I am thinking of asking a crowd up but dont know exactly who. I guess the same crowd as last year except [---] who of course is out of it now both on account of her being engaged and Anna's being home. Joe Morris will come I think O.K. and of coursewe will want some others I guess. Will thee please let me know (or ask father to) who are going to be at our house then and whether you care to have a big crowd or a crowd at all. Mary's engagement I think is very nice indeed. I know or thought that John was pretty fond of Mary but I did not know that they were going to get engaged. Altho Mary will be just as nice and good a friend as ever it will not make a lot of difference as she will not be eligible for doing things which we have always counted on her for when you wanteda person who was very good company to go off for a walk or a camping trip etc. I have not seen them yet but am very anxious to. Please give a great deal of love to all and with the same for thyself I am as ever thy lovng son
Algernon

Subject: Infants; Canoes and canoeing; Family; Health; Holidays; Marriage; Weddings;
Geographic Subjects: Atlantic City (N.J.); Browns Mills (N.J.); Rancocas Creek (N.J.);
Transcript:
Awbury
4/8/06

Dearest Mother
I am very sorry I have been so long in answering thy letter but after Edw wrote and told thee about father I did not feel it nearly so much as my mind tho I have been walking to work and tell thee that thy letter was much appreciated and also to let thee know that I still remembered there was such a person even tho I did not write.

Last week in spite of the fact that we no longer had the rummage sale on our minds was pretty full. On 2nd day we had our "Discipline Class" & on 3rd day Frank Ev & I read as usual. The baby has not been as well as she might beCOMMA having had a slight [bilious?] attack. So she has been a little more fruitful during the day tho she has been very good indeed when I have been over there in the evenings. Ev also has not been very well as she has had a mild attack of hives which have however now passed away I believe. While I am on the health of their family I might add that they heard the other daythat Ell has been right sick having had an attack of Gripp and there after getting better having a relapse from which I think she is now recovering. It is too bad that she should have been sick just as this timeCOMMA especially as they are getting ready to move. but it is a good thing that Aunt L is down there to look after them. To continue the health bulletin- Father seems to be pretty well and cheerful tho his ankle does not seem to get much better tho he [---] it. He drives a great deal and occassionally goes out to supper & dinner (I dont know how much he goes out to dinner). We have not had very much company in the evening tho Davis came up one night and Frank & Betty were over on 5th day night which Father enjoyed. I expect it would be good for him if we had some more company but it seems very hard to find a time when we have not got engagements.

Yesterday Joe Morris & I went up to the Rancocas and canoed. It was a very fine day in the morning and a pretty good afternoon tho a little disappointing after the way the day started. We had a first class time by ourselves and came home with that comfortable tired sleepy feeling. The main reason for our going was that I wanted to ship our canoe & Sam Emlen's up to Browns Mills so that we can come down the stream next 6th day which is Good Friday and therefore a holiday. A big crowd of people which Natalie and Elsie have asked are also going up to Browns Mills to stay over Easter and Ernest expects tobe one of them. Edw. & I were not asked as the girls seem to think that new blood is needed which sounds very well. I dont know exactly who all are going with them but the ladies are Natalie Elsie Mildred Sue Margaret [Werner] Katharine Buffum Eliz [Weston?]COMMA the fellows are ArtCOMMA BillCOMMA ErnestCOMMA and some other new bloods I am not certain who all.

I dont know certainly who of us are coming down in canoes but Ed & I will probably be in one boat & Sam & Marion in the other. Tho the latter are always more or less uncertain now! Thee knows they are expecting to married in June and Sam has asked Edw & myself to be ushers. By the way Ed wishes me to thank thee for him for thy letter and also to give thee his love. Harold is down at Atlantic CityCOMMA or rather in transit from Atlantic City I supposeCOMMA and Ernest has taken Esther Emlen over to the Shoemakers to heat some singing so they can not send their love. This morning I stopped for a few minutes at Uncle Franks and saw Esther. She seemed very bright & well. Ed stayed over there to dinner and then returned and took a drive with father while Frank & I went on a good long tramp.

Please excuse the writing blotts spelling etc for I am feeling rather sleepy & careless tho it is not late at allCOMMA the clock just having struck 9.30. I think I will however call this to a close & go to bed which I know will please thee. I have been getting to bed often much earlier than usual lately!! Please give a great deal of my love to Anna & remember me to Miss R. It will be very nice to see you all again. With great deal of love for thyself I am always thine
Algernon

Title: 1906 July 22COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Ernest Mervyn Evans:  1884-1911
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA ThomasCOMMA 1869-1955
Unidentified People: Milton; Ralph; Miss R.; Maggie; Jennie
Subject: Birthdays; Sports; Weather
Transcript:
Awbury
July 22

Dear MotherCOMMA
I believe that to-morrow is thy birthdayCOMMA and having no more useful or ornamental token to offer I will dedicate this epistle to the celebration of the happy occasion. Think of that! WellCOMMA dearCOMMA please take much love from thy sonCOMMA at any rateCOMMA and thanks for thy letter.

We are having some most welcome rain here this evening which I hope will continue for sometime but am a little afraid is only the edge of a gust. We had a little rain last night too so I hope that the dry spell is broken. Things are pretty well dried upCOMMA and Milton has had to start feeding the cows. Ralph is still staying with us which I certainly find very satisfactoryCOMMA though I am afraid that his being here prevents the boys from having some of their friendsCOMMA as four is about our numberCOMMA for comfort.

Tom Evans came over and played some tennis this afternoon and Alg has been taking supper with him this evening. He is certainly an amusing person.

Last evening Ed and Alg went over to Stokes' for supper.

Next seventh day we will probably be away as Ed and Alg are invited to the Wright's at [Bayhrad] and Alg and I are bidden to Suis. I don't know how Alg will fix it up. Please give FatherCOMMA Anna and Harold & Miss R. my love and Esther too if she is with you.

Maggie seems to bear up noblyCOMMA though Jennie has not been able to start to work yet. With much love from thy son.

Ernest

Title: 1910 September 2COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946

(Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; MorrisCOMMA Joe (Joseph Paul)COMMA 1879-1919; StokesCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1833-1917;
Unidentified People: the Roberts; Jack; Elizabeth Perot; Margaret;
Subject: Canoes and canoeing; Family; Health; Rheumatism; Sports;
Geographic Subjects: Germantown (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.); Jamestown (R.I.); Philadelphia (Pa.); Rancocas Creek (N.J.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.);
Transcript:
Phila
9/2/10

Dear Mother
I am going to try to mend my ways and write thee a real letter! Thee sees thee suffers from the fact thee is so good natured about our short comings. I am afraid I sometimes write to other members of the family and not to thee because I think thee will understand it is not because I do not love thee I do not write. I guess thee does understand this but likes to hear all the same.

I was surprised to hear thee started so soon for North East Harbor and I hope that gay house party did not wear thee out so thee was not rested enough to go. I hope at any rate thee will have a Chance to get rested at North East. It is too bad thee has had so much trouble with thy knee but perhaps a change of air will be good for it. I understand it is rheumatism- isnt it? There seems to be a great deal of it around. The other day- last 7th day it was- I had planned with Ernest to take a walk in the afternoon but suddenly in the middle of the morning a little rheumatism settled in my knee and it got quite sore so we went up to the Rancocas and canoed. I cured mine in a jiffy by rubbing it that night with [---] which I think is fine stuff. Has thee tried it on thy knee? I think it might help it.

Last night I very unexpectedly went up the Valley to the Roberts with Edward Jack & Joe. We had a very good time. Elizabeth Perot came over to supper and helped keep things moving. She has been having quite a bad time with rheumatism in one of her eyes but it is much better now. We spent the night and retuned to Phila this morning.

Tonight Ernest & I are expecting to go to Uncle Franks to supper and tomorrow we start for Woodbourne on the Black Diamond which gets us up there in time for supper. I am sorry that Evelyn fine stuff. Has thee tried it on thy knee? I think it might help it.

Last night I very unexpectedly went up the Valley to the Roberts with Edward Jack & Joe. We had a very good time. Elizabeth Perot came over to supper and helped keep things moving. She has been having quite a bad time with rheumatism in one of her eyes but it is much better now. We spent the night and retuned to Phila this morning.

Tonight Ernest & I are expecting to go to Uncle Franks to supper and tomorrow we start for Woodbourne on the Black Diamond which gets us up there in time for supper. I am sorry that Evelyn will not be up there but I am looking forward with much pleasure to seeing the others. I do not think Edw has planned to go away over the end of the week so he will be out at [Dimdale?].

Next week I suppose will bring quite a change in the numbers at Germantown as people generally have to come home about the 10th. It has been very quiet since we came back from the [---] and it will be nice to see some more people around once again.

I suppose the family will stay up at Jamestown until some time about the 23rd though I have not heard any date mentioned. Harold said he expected to come home about the 10th to do some work By the way I got from the barrel of Educators over at Grand[---] 5lbs the other day. I do now know how much they are a lb. & I wonder whether thee would mind settling with uncle Tom for them. I only took 5lbs as the barrel was pretty empty and I thought I had better have some in it. I think there are about 5lbs left.

Family affairs move along very quietly and very reasonably smoothly. Occassionally our fair Margaret gets a little ruffled under the collar but we have had nothing serious happen at all. As her second childhood is coming on she gets more and more forgetful so that sometimes I think it will not be long before we will be summoned to table and find it almost unused. The other night she admitted supper was late because she had put the lima beans on to cook but when she went to take them off she found nothing but boiling water as she had forgotten to put the beans in the pot!! It does very nicely for summer time when no one is in a hurry but it would be a little annoying if such things happened when we are busy.

The days are getting so short now we do not have much chance to play tennis unless we get an early start and as Ernest does not get out of town until the 505 at the earliest we have not played much. Edw and I however had a little practice. We have also been kept from playing by a great deal of [---] coolCOMMA- almost coldCOMMA- weather. Yesterday it rained very hard but has cleared up Today and I hope we will have clear weather over the end of the weakCOMMA though we will have a very good time no doubt even if the skies are cloudy.

Please give a great deal of love to Grandma. And with the same for thyself I am
Thy loving son
Algernon

Also please give my love to uncle T. (over) P.S.
I almost again forgot to thank thee for those very pretty little needle & thread holders which thee sent Harold & me. We really appreciated them very much and they were most convenient to have.

Title: 1882 September 3COMMA MeadowfieldCOMMA to sister
Creator: Hannah Bacon Evans:  1839-1939
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Eleanor Tyson StokesCOMMA 1840-1919; EvansCOMMA John WistarCOMMA 1836-1873; EvansCOMMA John WistarCOMMA 1870-1939; EvansCOMMA ThomasCOMMA 1869-1955; GarrettCOMMA Eleanor Tyson EvansCOMMA 1873-1953; StokesCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1833-1917; StokesCOMMA Hetty N. (Hetty Newlin)COMMA 1838-1899; StokesCOMMA Katharine Wistar EvansCOMMA 1841-1904;
Unidentified People: Aunt Lizzie; Joshua; Walter; Franky; Mrs Emmons; Susan Kito; Amy Roberts; Sophy Kimber; Mary Morton; the Newhalls;
Subject: Infants; Boardinghouses; Children; Death notices; Health; Insects; Quakers--Social life and customs; Weddings;
Geographic Subjects: Chester (Pa.); England; Germantown (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.); Maryland; Newport (R.I.); Philadelphia (Pa.);
Transcript:
Meadowfield 9.3.

My beloved sister
I feel as tho' I wanted to send thee another greeting before you leave NewportCOMMA thy last letter was very welcome with its good report of your welfareCOMMA I trust you have all continued in good case & will return home strengthened for the cares & duties of the winter. As to dear little EdwardCOMMA I do not suppose we shall know himCOMMA nor doubt he has changed muchCOMMA I hope he will make up his mind to take food when he really needs itCOMMA perhaps he may take to a cup & spurn if a bottle is too insulting to his dignity. Rebekah Smith's little boy is growing nicely & is a cute baby with the large dark eyesCOMMA your children ought to our ideasCOMMA & tho' his fractures are rather too large now for baby beauty he promises to develope that trait after awhile; at present his great charm is his good behaviorCOMMA which is a real comfort to his mamma as her nurse left her sooner than she wished & she has only a young girl to assist her in taking care of him. I suppose it will not be very long now before you are turning your faces homeward & it will be pleasant to think of your bring near us. tho' we shall not see one another for awhile. I am glad to hear from a letter to Katharine from Jthat you will not move into your own house until the 11th monthCOMMA as I would like to be on hand at that seasonCOMMA having a fancy for such dissipations. I have seen allusions in the papers to the burning of The Cliff HouseCOMMA but have not seen any account of the eventCOMMA what a favor you were not there! & how about the boardersCOMMA did they lose their things was anyone hurtCOMMA poor Mrs Emmons I hope she was not thereCOMMA (or thy Aunt Lizzie). By the way what do you hear of the latter. I trust her trip to England has been of use to herCOMMA when do you expect her back. I am sorry to hear that Hazen is not very strongCOMMA perhaps he did too muchCOMMA it seemed a very short time to be absent. Since our last letter to thee we have had a visit from Susan Kito & Amy RobertsCOMMA they are bothundemonstrative peopleCOMMA especially SusanCOMMA but they enjoyed being here I thinkCOMMA SK was not well & did not like to ride so we had a quiet timeCOMMA readingCOMMA talkingCOMMA examining flowers & looking at objects in the compound microscopeCOMMA one of Frank's late investments; they took tea at sister Eleanor's & also at Joshua's. Sister Eleanor's summer home was vacated on 3rd dayCOMMA sheCOMMA TomCOMMA EllieCOMMA & Walter drove home with the two horses & carriage she spent one night at Arondale & one at HM Stokes at Chester & reached Germantown on 5th day evening. Hetty & Wistar have gone to "Uncle Gideon's" & Betty is staying with us; the stay down here has been a real succesCOMMA the children have been very well & happyCOMMA have found much to interest & occupy them.Wistar & Franky have spent many hours in "bug hunts" & do manifest much zeal in the collection of beetlesCOMMA butterflys & mothsCOMMA & really have quite a large number; we labor under great difficulty as far as the study of the subject is concernedCOMMA as we have no books on Entomology except one by [Wood?] which treats of British insectsCOMMA I quite want to get some good work & be able to learn the names of some of the creatures the boys have. I have wandered away from my starting pointCOMMA sister Eleanorfound the quiet of the country life & the absense of the many demands on her time & thoughts that she has to meet in Germantown a great restCOMMA & altho' the house has not much to attract as regards situation it did not make the same difference to her it would to usCOMMA as she is so fond of riding she was out almost daily & enjoyed taking others drives. Thee may remember Katharine & I find great comfort in sitting under the trees or lying in the hammocks when not busy sewing. I suppose Hetty will stay down some weeks yetCOMMA her trip to Mt [Desert?] brokeinto her summer & I think she dont feel at all ready to leave Maryland. John & Walter came down yesterday with Frank but dont expect to make much of a visit as they talk of going back tomorrow. We heard a report that Sophy Kimber was to be married at Newport this summerCOMMA does thee know if it is soCOMMA her certificate has been sent on from 12th stCOMMA we shall miss her from Germantown she is so efficient & willing. Now my dear sister when thee writesCOMMA which I hope may be [---] longCOMMA please tell us how thee isCOMMA Katharine wishes to know if thee has picked up any fat in the cool airCOMMA how does thy nurse getonCOMMA I hope she has proved an efficient help. It is raining quite heavily nowCOMMA which is not as acceptable as at some seasonsCOMMA but when I think how we have longed for it in former days I dont like complaining. The season of canning has arrived & folks in this part of the country are busy enough putting up cornCOMMA tomatoes & peaches &cCOMMA I should feel dubious about eating the products of some of the factoriesCOMMA as they employ Bohemians whose cleanliness is more than doubtful. We were quite startled to see the death of Mary Morton yesterdayCOMMA she spent a few days with Rebekah some 2 weeks agoCOMMA but was not well then & wished to get to PhilaCOMMA it is such a favor she went up when she did or she might have died here. Please give my love to thy mother & LillyCOMMA kiss the dear children for me & accept for thyself a message of warmaffection from thy attached sister K sends love Hannah B. Evanscan thee tell us anything of the Newhalls. Ive not heard from A for some time & fear her mother is more poorly.

Notes: Envelope includes original two-cent stamp with profile of George Washington.
Transcript:
Meadow Farm
8 Mo 8th/84

My dear little Anna

I have thought of thee very often since thee left us on 4th day morning and shall be glad to hear how thee and Ethel made out on your journeyCOMMA did she behave well? and was thee very tired when thee got to Montrose? I expect you have had a great many nice plays togetherCOMMA I mean theeCOMMA AgnesCOMMA Franky and EllieCOMMA not Ethel and thee! I left Germantown the day after thee did and came down to Maryland with cousins George Emlen and Katy StokesCOMMA Edith came over to Conowingo to meet usCOMMA with RobertCOMMA and they put the trunk in the front of the carriage and sat on it instead of a seatCOMMA cousin George rode up with Horace StokesCOMMA so we all got home nicelyCOMMA only the roads are very rough and we were well shaken up. Just after dinner today we had a very hard rain and WistarCOMMA Edith and Franky put on thin bathing clothes and ran about out doors until it was nearly over and then they went down to the streamthat crosses our lane and here they found the water so deep they took another bath in thatCOMMA which they thought was great fun. They have a kitten a little larger than yours but she is nearly all white except her tail which is grey with a white tip; aunt Kate says her name is Pennyroyal but Edith don't like that at allCOMMA and Wistar says she ought to be called Tip. We expect Henry home tomorrow and shall be very glad to see him. Cousin GeorgeCOMMA Ellie and the children are not staying with us nowCOMMA theyare at Gideon Smiths but the childrenCOMMA all except SamCOMMA are to go home tomorrow. I hope Franky's trumpet did not get bent going upCOMMA and that he liked it and the game. I am afraid Aunt Lilly won't care to have him blow the trumpet very near the houseCOMMA perhaps you take it when you go out rowing on the lake or walking in the woods. I hope thee will get quite strong and fat and have a very good time. Give my love to aunt Lilly and Anna and a great deal to thy self with a kiss from thy aunt Hannah.The Children have all gone to bed or they would send love to thee.Anna Cope Evans
Dimock PO
Susquehanna Co
Penna.

Transcript:
Meadow Farms
8 Mo 16.85.

My beloved brother

Thy letter of love and sympathy was very acceptable for tho' our friends cannot do much for us just now we do appreciate their sympathy. I am sorry I cannot tell thee that dear Katy is betterCOMMA her fever still continues tho her temperature is one degree down this morning. I believe I told thee the typhoid symptoms had disappearedCOMMA which conclusion I jumped at from hearing the Dr. say the trouble about the abdomen was goneCOMMA and tongue clearing offCOMMA but on saying something like it to the Dr.COMMA he replied he thought they seemed to be developing much more then in the first weeks of the sickness. Dr. Newlin Stokes came down to G. Smith's funeral yesterdayCOMMA saw Katy and had a consultation with Dr. Sapington. Yesterday for the 1st time a few spots appeared in the abdomen and the Dr.s both said that was the 9th day of the typhoid feverCOMMA so dear child she has a long siege before her yet. It was a great satisfaction that Dr. Stokes said the case had been treated just as he should have done and he had no change to suggest except giving valerian instead of bromide to quiet her at night. They both unite in giving little medicineCOMMA only quinen to keep up her strength and all the nourishment she can take. Dr. [Lapingson?] thought perhaps Valentines extract did not suit her so we now squeeze the bloodOut of raw beef and give her that every four hours. Sam will send us down a druggists pressCOMMA which will be a help in getting the juice out. Both Dr.'s said we ought to have a nurseCOMMA Dr. Stokes said he know of one he thought we could getCOMMA Frank telegraphed for her and I think Thomas Cope will probably see her for us tomorrow and if suitable send her down. It will be a comfort to have some one who is skilful and can move and change Katy with less fatigue than we do. Frank stays with Katy part of every night and helps much with the nursingCOMMA but Katherine is so anxious and nervous I fear she will be quite laid up unless we have some help. Katy's fever is not highCOMMA 102 2/10 the highest her temperature has reached and todayit is a degree less. She has little disturbance of the bowels and no head acheCOMMA her mouth and throat are very uncomfortableCOMMA feel gummy and sore and she feels very weak and weary. Slept but little last night and the hours were long and tedious for herCOMMA she is very patient but at times is nervous. Edith seems to be gainingCOMMA is taken down stairs everyday and takes tea with usCOMMA Dr. took her temperature today and found it a little below normalCOMMA says she must have a little brandy. It is rather depressing for her and [Esther?] and franklyCOMMA we are so taken up with Katy and the house has to be kept so quietCOMMA so it is proposed for them to go to Uncle's for a few days and when Edith is stronger they may go to Awbury. If sister Eleanor takes Ellie away perhaps the girls could accompany her. I am glad to know you are better for Newport airCOMMA we had a very nice letter from dear Rachel please thank her for it and let her see this as I shall not have time to write to her now. I rejoice to think thee spent some days at Batemans and do hope thee feels stronger for itCOMMA thee will be lonely at Awbury with so many of both families away. With much love from usAll I am thy attached sister Hannah. I remember this is thy birthday.

Title: 1885 August 19COMMA to Jonathan Evans
Creator: Hannah Bacon Evans:  1839-1939

Transcript:
8 Mo 19. [1885]
Dr says Katy is holding her own very wellCOMMA her temperature is rather lower this morning than at the same time yesterday. 101 today & her skin more natural. She slept a good deal last nightCOMMA but does not seem quite so drowsy this morning & therefore more conscious of her discomforts. Dear child she gets discouraged at timesCOMMA the days seem so long. I was writing for a tooth brush but Katharine says Katy has just got a nice soft one. Sam sent us down a press for the beefCOMMA so we can get the juice out with less labor. I hope Ernest is doing wellCOMMA my love to Rachel & the others at Newport. With love thine truly
H.B.E.Jonathan Evans
160 North 22nd St.
Philadelphia
Pa

Creator: Hannah Bacon Evans:  1839-1939

Notes: Describes the funeral of Elizabeth Waln Cope.
Transcript:
[Tear this up when you have read it. I have answered it.]

Locust Avenue
8 Mo 3rd

My dear sister

I am once more at home and quite miss hearing of thy welfare and dear Anna's from Jonathan's letters. I hope you still continue to gain and enjoy the mountain air. When I got home last 2nd dayCOMMA I felt very much used up with the heat & the change in airCOMMA but now have become accustomed to it and feel quite wellCOMMA tho' the amount of moisture in the air makes things damp & sticky. No doubt thee has heard particulars of E.W. Copes last hoursCOMMA the close must have been very peacefulCOMMA both Ellie & Madgie express their feelings of thankfulness that their mother did not have to endure long confinement and great suffering. The funeral was smallCOMMA so many are awayCOMMA S. Morris and E Allen bore testimony to her characterCOMMA there was nothing said at the grave but there was such a sweetCOMMA quiet feeling as we stood silently there in the evening lightsCOMMA everything looking so beautiful & peacefulCOMMA words did not seem to be needed. E. Allen said after meeting today to Eleanor & meCOMMA that after sheheard of E.W. Copes death she went into her room and such a sweet feeling came over herCOMMA she felt it was a forecast of the rest & peace into which Elizabeth Cope had entered. I rode to the ground with cousin Rebecca EvansCOMMA she spoke of cousin ElizabethCOMMA said the letter thee wrote her had been such a particular comfort and help to herCOMMA that Rebecca had felt she must write & tell thee but has been rather burdened with callsCOMMA so I said I would let thee know about itCOMMA I think R sent her love to thee. Will & Grace have both had mumpsCOMMA and little MaryCOMMA (Alice'sdaughter) has been very sickCOMMA she is now gaining down at the Dennis and Grace has been there with them. Cousin Wm & John Rhoads have gone to T. Brown's camp for their vacation. I send thee one of Esthers letters as thee may be interested to hear something of the Conference. It seems to have been a time of spiritual refreshment & uplifting & I hope may prove of use to the building up of the Church. Eleanor says the spirit of love & unity was very markedCOMMA Alfred urged that all [---] and feelings of antagonism between old & youngCOMMA conservative & progressive should be laidasideCOMMA which seemed to be the case. Alfred seems to feel his mind relieved of the concernCOMMA he went back to Bupshire yesterday & is going on to Northfield. Frank Goodhue also went to Bupshire will spend today there & go on to Brattleboro taking little Mary with him. Edith Silver came up on 5th day eveCOMMA it was very pleasant to see herCOMMA she went home yesterdayCOMMA Betty & little Elizabeth & Sam Mason all went with her. Betty intends spending a couple of weeks at Swallowfield where she hopes to have a good rest. Francis Jr is at Bupshire so all the children are cared for. Sister Eleanor & Tom I believe are going to Bupshire soon & Wistar to the South on business so the house will be deserted for awhile. Katy & the childrenpropose coming home on 3rd day. Frank came on to the funeral but went back last nightCOMMA I am glad for him to have a visit there. Emma Edwards fell in her house and broke her hipCOMMA she is now very ill not expected to live & her life is not to be [---] under the circumstances. I had an active time last week attending meetings but got on better than I expected toCOMMA tomorrow is Phila Quarterly Mg & 5th day oursCOMMA after that I shall take a rest and do a little here at homeCOMMA as I see many things that need looking after. I dont know when Esther will come home probably in about a week. A great deal of love to dear Anna & also for thyself from thy attached sister

Hannah B. Evans

Title: 1902 July 27COMMA JamestownCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA Hannah BaconCOMMA 1839-1939; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; LeedsCOMMA Morris EvansCOMMA 1869-1952; ScattergoodCOMMA Mary Cope EmlenCOMMA 1878-1975; StokesCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1833-1917; StokesCOMMA Katharine Wistar EvansCOMMA 1841-1904; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862; StorkCOMMA Theophilus Baker
Unidentified People: Mrs. Wright; Miss Hacker; Buffums; Phoebe Gifford; Elsie Bettle; Sam Kimber; Franklin Nordhoff;
Subject: Older people; Flowers; Food habits; Leisure; Photographs; Wounds and injuries
Transcript:
Jamestown
July 27th

Dear Mother

I am going to write thee a Sunday epistle as I believe I have not been writing to thee lately more than three times a week. To-day is another cloudy day though early this morning the sun was shining. It has now been cloudy since a week ago yesterday and we have decided that it would be nice if it would clear up. We had quite a large meeting this morning. Phoebe Gifford who they say is within ten months of being a hundred was there and spoke a few words. Elsie Bettle and Mrs. Wright drove up with Miss Hacker. Father and Aunt Hannah and Ernest took a driveafter meeting- Edward came down with the Kimbers and Sam and I walked. Aunt Hannah is going home to-night but Sam is going to wait and go down with Uncle Frank Stokes whoCOMMA I believeCOMMA is going to bring Aunt Kate up on third day.

We had fresh corn for dinner yesterday and it certainly was good. It seems very early for it but they say it is "island corn." Tonight we are going over to Buffums to hear them sing hymns.

May Emlen came up on Sixth day by train and I think she is going over too. Little Franklin NordhoffCOMMA who thee knows broke both armsCOMMA now has them out of the slings and can use them. Tell Anna that that roll of films which we had developed at Rolfes have been sent on by Alg. They certainly do look weird. Thee knows that Aunt Hannah went to Morris Leeds and sent him some of that blue flower that grows up at Conanicut Park. He did not know what it was but found out from Stewardson Brownthat it was an English flower called Sheeps-bit Jasione MontanaCOMMA and that it only grew in certain parts of Rhode Island and Connecticut.

The golf club is a great success and has over 250 members. The other day father went round in 62 strokes which is the family record. A gentlemen named [---]W. Kemble went round in 37 the other day and broke the professional record by six. Yesterday Father and Aunt Hannah went down to Shoemakers to call but found that they were out. After they came home Father and I took a little drive up the island and met Uncle Theo. He said that Aunt Anna has been quite sick with the abcess on her throat but was better now.

It is after dinner time now and as Edward is writing to Anna and Father will probably write another letter to thee I think I will close.

I am thy loving son
Harold

Give my love to Anna and tell her I expect to print some pictures from those films and will send her some when finished.

Title: 1905 March 11COMMA Haverford CollegeCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; SharplessCOMMA IsaacCOMMA 1848-1920;
Unidentified People: Dr. Babbitt; Emily Fox; Fred Sharpless;
Subject: Haverford College--History; Haverford College--Students; Weather;
Notes: Letter describes the illness and absence of Haverford College President Isaac Sharpless.
Transcript:
Dear Mother
It certainly does not seem over two weeks ago that I saw you at AldineCOMMA and I can scarcely tell what I have been doing with myself. The Sophomore-Freshman debate caame off the Third-day of the week after I saw youCOMMA and so I was pretty busy preparing for that. Unfortunately we lost. It was the first thing the Freshmen had beaten us inCOMMA so we were rather sour. Then the next night came the Entertainment for the Preston Boys' Club. I had no idea of staying till the dance but go to talking and didn't get back till after twelve! It was very good fun and I enjoyed it very much. It is rather good fun to watch other people dance even though you don't dance yourself. It was a success financially tooCOMMA and we cleared $156.25 all of whichCOMMA I am glad to say was given to the Boys' Club through Dr. Babbitt. For a wonder the newspaper report about Emily Fox and the Biddles was true except that I think it was greatly exaggerated. Detectives have been put on the caseCOMMA I believe and they hope to recover at least some of the things. I don't know whether they think they lost it or that it was stolen. It certainly was mighty hard luck as I believe some of Emily's things were valuable on account of being heir looms.

Ernest's kneeCOMMA I think is just about all right. He can walk around on it all right but I imagine it is still weak.

The weather here has been quite warm and the snow has been melting pretty fastCOMMA but there is a good deal of ice over things and it takes a good while to melt that off. To-day however is quite cool againCOMMA though I imagine it will warm up toward the middle of the day as the sun has so much power. It sounds fine to hear of May days and violets and daffodils but it will not be so very long before we too shall be getting springCOMMA for here it is about a third of the way through March. It certainly seems funny to think that there are only three more weeks of the third quarter left; for the fourth quarter goes by like grease-lightening. I am glad I am not in Ernest's shoes.

To-night the gymnasium competition with Lehigh University comes off and I certainly hope we win. Last week our team went up to RutgersCOMMA and when the last event began we were several points behindCOMMA but we won the event and the meet by one point! I hope it will be as exciting to-night.

It is fine to hear of all that Anna can do. Please give her a great deal of love from me and tell her that this letter is for her too. I suppose thee has heard of President Sharpless' illness. He has not been at college for nearly three weeksCOMMA I think. They took him into the Pennsylvania Hospital where Fred Sharpless is one of the physiciansCOMMA but he is better now.

Last Fourth day afternoon we had another festivity in the way of a Faculty tea for the Sophomores. It was rather good funCOMMA though I don't think much of teas. They are too stiff and formal.

I think I shall have to cry a halt as my slender stock of news is about exhausted. With lots of love for you both and thanking thee very much for thy letterCOMMA

Thy very affectionate son Harold.

Title: 1905 September 5COMMA Jamestown R.I.COMMA to Mother
Creator: Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; GrahameCOMMA KennethCOMMA 1859-1932; KiplingCOMMA RudyardCOMMA 1865-1936;
Unidentified People: Whitalls; Lippetts; Wetherells; Miss Richardson; Miss Hodge; Mr. Wood; Art Brown; Paul; Margaret Mellor; Eleanor Haydock; Elsie Smith; Joe; Jim; Greta; Gilbert Stuart; Colin;
Subject: Books; Leisure; Letter writing; Sailing; Sports; Tennis;
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Kingston (Mass. : Town); Plymouth (Mass.); White Mountains (N.H. and Me.);
Transcript:
Jamestown R.I.
Sept 5th 1905

Dear Mother

I was just about to write to theeCOMMA in fact I started a letter last nightCOMMA getting as far as the dateCOMMA- when I received thine this morning. I wrote to Mr. Wood on Sixth day and I suppose he has received it by this time. It is rather a new experience writing to elderly gentlemenCOMMA so I hope I didn't say anything queer.

Art Brown arrived a week ago last First-day and he and Paul and I had a very good time. Art is very different from the rest of mankind- he is so very anxious to please and writes letters at such an awful rate. In one mail he sent eight or nine letters including postals. Isn't that awful? We jollied him a great dealCOMMA Paul and ICOMMA too much I am afraidCOMMA but he was so good-natured about it that it was hard to know when to stop. On Third-dayCOMMA after we had been to tennisCOMMA Margaret Mellor asked us all to go out sailing. I could not go as I had to play in the tennis tournamentCOMMA but Paul and Art went and had a rather amusing time. Then she asked us down to a marshmallow roast on Fifth-day night. We were not very keen about going but nevertheless went and had a very crazy time. In the first place the crowd did not know each other at allCOMMA- some of them were very gay and sporty while others were sedate and sober like myself. Paul and Art spent most of the time having a marshmallow fight. Eleanor Haydock was there (this was the one saving feature of the evening) and so I managed to survive. The consequence of these two invitations wasthat we decided we ought to try to do some thing in return. Sixth-day was Arts last day so we tried to find out what he wanted to do and finally decided to take a sail in the morning and the Ocean Drive in the afternoon. Paul decided he would rather play tennis so Art and I went down to the Bay Voyage and asked Margaret Mellor and Eleanor Haydock to go. I am not especially keen about Margaret Mellorm so sheCOMMA of courseCOMMA wentCOMMA while EleanorCOMMA who was staying at [---] Wharton'sCOMMA decided she had better return and see whether they had anything for her to do. We took three large fat magazines and managed to have a pretty good time. In the afternoon we took the Ocean Drive and nearly died laughing. The swells were out in force with their footmen and coachmenCOMMA andCOMMA as
Paul and Art were not much used to themCOMMA some of their remarks were very amusing. They kept speaking to the different ones they passed and then went off in fits of laughter. We drove back over the hills back of the golf-courseCOMMA and it certainly was mighty pretty. Art left that night and went down to Elsie Smith's house-party the next day. Paul left on Seventh day morning on the nine o'clock train for Boston and went up to the White Mts (as far as Plymouth by the same train as we took). He is at present at the Flume HouseCOMMA and I should not be so very much surprised if he came over your way some of these days. His father and motherCOMMA Ellis and he are going to stay there for a couple of weeks and Paul told me that his father had been going up there for the last fifty years and had only missed about
ten. I don't know whether this is true or not but Paul said so! Alg and the rest of the crowd arrived about an hour after Paul departed this island (You say "departed this life" so I don't see why you should not say "departed this island"). Things began to move [instanter?] and the first thing done was a game of roof-ball in which Art and I defeated Joe and Alg most ignominiously after which we inquired if they could play marbles or any such game! A little baby-in-the-hat was the result but unfortunately was interrupted by swimming. On Seventh-day afternoon Jim asked me to race with him in his new half-rater (15 footer). I accepted with great pleasure and went down to Whitall's to lunch. Six of the little boatsCOMMA all exactly alikeCOMMA started. There were two of E.D. Morgan's (one sailed by his daughter and the other byhis son) one of the Lippitt'sCOMMA on of the Wetherill's and one sailed by Miss Grosvenor. Miss Morgan did not understand the course and started off wrongCOMMA but instead of giving up the race she kept her nerve and came chasing after us. When we rounded the last buoy we were third but were soon passed by another boat. From that time on Miss Morgan and we did not follow the rest but showed our independenceCOMMA and we won while she came in second. I was pretty nearly as glad to see her beat the rest of them as I was that we won. It was Jim's first victory so I think I must have been his mascot! When we awoke on First-day morning a good old southeaster was snoring outside but we braved the elements and went to meeting. Comong home it rained so hard that it went right through my rain coatCOMMAand rendered thy little Willie boy quite damp. Second-day was still fine and wet so we fooled round the house most of the day. In the morning we read a couple of Kenneth Grahame's "Dream Days" storiesCOMMA and they certainly are pretty good. We also read a crazy story by Paul [---] entitled "Love Will Find a Way" and "The Maltese Cat" by Rudyard Kipling. In the afternoon we tried to take a sail but failed as Father had told the captain he could have a holiday. However we went up to Whitall's and Greta and Alg and I went out in a row-boat with a sail in it. The little craft went sideways pretty nearly as fast as it did forwards so we did not get very far. The rest of them went out in the rowboat and took a row. This morning was cloudywhen we got upCOMMA but we had decided to go on a picnic over to Gilbert Stuart's so we did and before we had fairly started the sun shone forth in all his grandeur and we had a fine day. I took Colin along and he behaved very well and seemed to enjoy it though he was pretty tired before we got home. Altogether we walked about thirteen miles so thee sees we had plenty of exercise. After lunch we walked back toward Kingston and got a good view of the country. We had to hustle back to catch the five-thirty boatCOMMA but when we got to Saunders town we found we had time enough to eat some ice cream at a fair that was going on behind the hotel. We walked over from the West Ferry and then JoeCOMMA ArtCOMMA Alg and I took a short swim at Whitall's. It is getting pretty lateCOMMA the news and this sheet are rapidly coming to a close and I am tired so good night.With lots of love for both thee and Anna
I am as ever
Harold

Please give my love to Miss Richardson. Katherine and Jacquee say to thank thee very much for thy letter. If any of you think of it you can remember me to the Leeds and the Hodges. Tell me about the tournament and give my congratulations to the young Miss Hodge if she won.

Title: 1907 July 11COMMA ChesterCOMMA to Grandparents
Creator: Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; Edward VIICOMMA King of Great BritainCOMMA 1841-1910; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; LewisCOMMA William DraperCOMMA 1867-1949; WestminsterCOMMA Hugh Richard Arthur GrosvenorCOMMA Duke ofCOMMA 1879-1953;
Subject: Kings and rulers; Landscape; Ocean Voyages and Travels; Ruins; Tintern Abbey; Transportation; Wales--Description and Travel; Weather;
Geographic Subjects: Beddgelert (Wales); Bude (England); Caernarfon (Wales); Chester (England); Devon (England); Exmoor (England); Ilfracombe (England); London (England); Lynmouth (England); Lynton (England); Newport (R.I.); Porlock (England); Tintagel (England); Tintern (Wales);
Transcript:
Chester
July 11thCOMMA 1907

My Dearest GrandparentsCOMMA

I have been meaning to write to you for some timeCOMMA but somehow have not got it done so farCOMMA with the exception of one poor postal.

WellCOMMA we have been having the best kind of a time. The voyage was most enjoyable for there were some very jolly people on board and there was lots of deck-room for games.

Since landing we have had a good deal of rainy weather but we don't seem to mind rain at allCOMMA and it has not interfered with our plans except once or twice when we have taken the coach instead of walking in the rain. The cold tooCOMMA for it has been pretty chilly at timesCOMMA has been rather a blessing than otherwise for it has made our walks and sightseeing tours all the more enjoyableCOMMA and the soft coal fires have been very nice and cheerful.

Our trip through Devonshire was a great successCOMMA though we can scarcely call it a walking trip as we walked only two days instead of four. From London we went straight to TintagelCOMMA arriving there Seventh day evening. The cliffs are perfectly magnificent and we spent most of First day morning admiring them from King Arthur's Castle which is on a beautiful promontory. Finding it was impossible to get our bags to Bude on the Sabbath we took the only course open and drove thereCOMMA taking them with us. It was disappointing to miss the walkCOMMA but we had the more time at Tintagel of which we were very glad. Bude was rather uninterestingCOMMA but the walk from there to Clovelly is certainly charmingly quaintCOMMA though the tourists haveCOMMA I supposeCOMMA come in such swarms that it seems as though the place were artificially natural (if you can guess what I mean by that). From Clovelly we went to Ilfracombe by boat and thence we coached to Lynton. Here again we had expected to walk but were again preventedCOMMA this time by rain. Lynton and Lynmouth took my fancy very muchCOMMA and Paul Brown and I had a delightful walk up the Valley of the Lyn to Watermeet (where the East and West Lyn come together)The next day we walked to Porlock in spite of the rain. We were very fortunateCOMMA howeverCOMMA and each time a shower overtook us we were able to reach shelter. The darkCOMMA low-flying clouds with here and there a burst of sunshine rather added to the wildness of Exmoor and it was not hard to imagine that the Doones might almost still be living in some of the wild valleys. We saw a herd of the wild Exmoor ponies but were not fortunate enough to see any of the red-deer which we were told at Porlock are not at all uncommon. From Porlock we went to Tintern by train. It was a rather tedious journey with a good deal of waiting. The two place are only about thirty miles apart in a straight lineCOMMA but it took us six hours toreach our destination.

Tintern Abbey is a fine old ruin and takes you back to the Middle AgesCOMMA giving the whole town an air of antiquity. The little chapel on the hillCOMMA which they say is older than the abbey was also very interesting and we spent last Seventh-day morning (till train time) wandering around them and taking pictures of them.

We came straight to Chester from TinternCOMMA and I must say I was rather disappointed in it. The Cathedral is fine but the Walls do not amount to very much it seems to one. We left here First-day evening and went to Carnarvon where we were very much interested in the Castle which dates I believe from 1256. At Carnarvon the rain again interfered with our walkingCOMMA and this time it rained so hard that the coach did not run and we were obliged to go to Bedd-gelert by train. In some ways Bedd-gelert appeals to me more than most of the places we have seen. It is such a quiet little townCOMMA "far from the madd'ning crowd's ignoble strifeCOMMA" nestled in the heart of the Welsh MtsCOMMA that I felt I should like to have more time there. In the afternoon it stopped raining and we walked down the Pass of Aberglaslyn where they say the cliffs rise eight hundred feet from the road. It is especially fine now as the recent rains have filled the streams very full and the little brooks tumbling over themselves down the mountainsides are very beautiful.

When we awoke the next morning we were again greeted by the pleasant patter of rainCOMMA but we decided to walk to Beltus-y-coed at any rate. I am very glad we did as it soon stopped raining and it was a very pretty walk. At Capel-Curig we again saw the king (we had seen him twice in London) this time in plain every-day clothes in an automobileCOMMA on his way to Carnarvon. The people had gathered from far and near and greeted him enthusiastically. I was interested to her them sing the Welsh national anthem in their native languageCOMMA which is certainly most unintelligible. This morning we returned here and this afternoon visited the Cathedral after which Arthur and I went to see Eaton HallCOMMA the Duke of Westminster's place. As he is now in London we were allowed to go over his houseCOMMA of course for a shillingCOMMA (everything is for a shilling) and were very much interestedto see how he lives. It is a most magnificent placeCOMMA "rich but not gaudy" and somehow seems much more "fit" than some of the summer cottages at NewportCOMMA though I imagineCOMMA as far as money goes that Newport's "cozy little cottages" are quite as grand. Eaton Park is a beautiful stretch of land about three miles (or more) long and the deer grazing in the open fields were very pretty.

I have now come to the end of my letterCOMMA and as it is growing late I must close. Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Tom and to Aunt C. and Uncle W and their family and keep a great great deal for yourselves
from your loving grandson
Harold.

Title: 1906 September 30COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; EmlenCOMMA George WilliamsCOMMA 1853-1938; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; LewisCOMMA Esther Margaret EmlenCOMMA 1890-1927; ScattergoodCOMMA Mary Cope EmlenCOMMA 1878-1975;
Unidentified People: Miss Richardson; Dr Van Pelt; Dr Bassett; Eleanor Haydock; Anita Downing; John; Billy Haines; Miss Janvier; Thomas Janvier;
Subject: Health; Leisure; Philadelphia Cricket Club; Rhode Island--Description and Travel; Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Jamestown (R.I.); Orange (N.J.); Rancocas Creek (N.J.); Wickford Harbor (R.I.); Wissahickon Creek (Pa.);
Notes: Includes news of the engagement between Billy Haines and the niece of Thomas Janvier.
Transcript:
Awbury
9/30/1906

Dear MotherCOMMA

It certainly does seem much more than two days since we parted from thee and AnnaCOMMA Miss Richardson and Harold on the ferry wharf at Jamestown. I don't know why the time should seem so long but it is even hard to realize that only last Tuesday father and I were looking out over the Bay blue as could be in the sunlight of a splendid September day as we sat on the deck of the "General" on our way to Wickford. It seemed a great shame to spend so good a day in that stuffy parlor car.

We got through the packing very comfortablyCOMMA and (although father did say that in the middle of one night he thought we would never be able to get it all done) with very little worry I think. The only thing now is that none of the freight has yet come. We seem to be getting along very nicely on what we have brought.

Since my arrival at home I have been to see two of my doctor friends. Dr. Van Pelt and Dr. Bassett the latter fixed me up without doing anything very muchCOMMA a lucky escape for me because I haven't been to the dentist for over a year and Dr. Van Pelt is going to make an examination of my eyes with the aid of drops later on in the year. He goes away tomorrow and thought there would hardly be time to do it now.

Last sixth day afternoon Father and I took a drive. We went up through the WissahickonCOMMA pretty as usual though the foliage hasn't changed much and then stopped at the Philadelphia Cricket Club grounds where I met Alg. And we had some tennis. Father seems pretty well I think and says he has enough to keep him busy in town for some time so perhaps it is just as well the freight hasn't come yet or he might try to do something at once.

Yesterday I went up the Rancocas with HaroldCOMMA George and EstherCOMMA Eleanor Haydock and Anita Downing. I believe Harold thought some of the members of the house party wouldn't be able to go so did not try to get there to-gether this time. In spite of the fact that it was a threatening day and rained just as we reached the ferry and notwithstanding the fact that Harold and I forgot to eat any lunch we had a very nice time and escaped any wetting. It cleared up before we got back and the moonlight was beautiful. Our only accidents wereCOMMA I thinkCOMMA that Esther [---] on the [---] of a very irascible old Irish woman in the trolley car who swore around at a great rate and was not at all mollified by Esther's apology. Then Eleanor dropped her umbrellaafter meeting broke up. John and Mary Emlen were there and altho. they tried to get off pretty quickly thee may be sure a lot of us caught them and detained them for a word or two.

Alf. is coming to us for supper which will be very nice. Alg. is now reclining on the sofa reading and sends his love to thee and Anna and Aunt Lilly. Before I close I must ask if thee has heard of the latest engagement--Billy Haines to a Miss JanvierCOMMA of OrangeCOMMA NJ and niece of Thomas Janvier who writes for the magazines somewhat.
[---] in Alg's message of love to you all and [---]

They affectionate son
Edward

Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient: EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Eleanor Tyson StokesCOMMA 1840-1919; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; GoldsmithCOMMA OliverCOMMA 1730?-1774
Unidentified People: Polly; Miss Richardson; Mrs Stedman; Miss Webb; Cousin Hannah; Cousin Sallie
Subject: Books; Clothing and dress; Flowers; Health; Photographs
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Friday the 15th
2/16/01

Dearest FamilyCOMMA

I have just been reading a very nice letter from PollyCOMMA which I was rightly glad to get. If you think of it tell her so with a great deal of love and many thanks from me. Then I have some more beautiful flowers to thank thee forCOMMA Father dear. They were truly beautifulCOMMA and are still lovely though some of themCOMMA the roses especiallyCOMMA show their age! Miss Richardson thought they were packed better and seemed fresher if anything than the ones from [Waltemates?]. I suppose my attack of Grippe was the excuse for my having theseCOMMA but I am afraid it sounded more than it was. I dont think the doctor was atallsure it was GrippeCOMMA & if it was I dont think Ive heard of such a light case! Thank thee [---] so much COMMA dearieCOMMA for the lovely flowers and the letter that came with them. I'd like some more of the last mentioned article whenever thee has time & feels like it but thee really mustnt send me any more of the former. While we are on the flower subjectCOMMA just pay thyself $5.00 from meCOMMA will thee? I have moneyin bank I thinkCOMMA & my flower bill this month or lately will about amount to that I think. I have been indulging myself by sending some to different people. Some violets to Miss Stedman (who has had a cold) etc. People have been so kind to me here.

I havent got to the boys photo. yetCOMMA there are so many things to say. I think it is mighty niceCOMMA & I am so glad to have it. It is a little like seeing them. It stands on my bureau & this morning I burst out laughing just looking at it. I could just imagine from seeing their expressions the kind of time they had getting it taken. Edwards expression especially makes me laugh. Thank you all for it ever so much. You must feel somewhat repaid for all your troubleCOMMA for it is so nice to have it. If AuntLilly or Ellie have room I think I'd like some of my other photos. Any that you can find. Also my other belt buckleCOMMA if you can find it easily. I think I had it at Conanicut. It is a clasp & looks something like silver. It isnt important at all. If you have a copy of "She Stoops to Conquer" that isnt too nice perhaps you would send that too by themCOMMA ormail it to me later if you havent finished reading it by the time they come. I just thought maybe I'd like to read it as you all are. Oh & if you know where my visiting cards are I think it would just as well for me to have some & a card case if you can find one. I dont suppose I need themCOMMA but I might want one for something later on. I'd rather also like to have my black bloomers (sort ofsilk they are made of) sometimeCOMMA but there is no hurry.

I am sending theeCOMMA dearest MotherCOMMA something I started for thee last FallCOMMA but have only finished lately. I thought thy old one was pretty well worn. I dont think I showed thee when thee was here the hound glass I got Miss Webb to get me as a birthday present from thee. Does thee remember thee told me to get one & never did? It is a very nice one I think. The usual shape & white celluloid I think. Now I am talking to thee. I'll just say one or two things I want to. First Miss Richardson asked me to thank thee for thy message & to remember her to thee. She is so nice. Sweet & jolly- I think I am very fortunate. Thee ought to hear us laughing over things sometimes. Sheis young & ready for fun. Then if thee thinks of it when thee writes to Cousin Hannah wont thee give her my dear love and thanks for the little book & the letter she sent me at Christmas. And please give my love to Cousin Sallie too and thank them both for the very nice message they sent me when I was first taken sick. I have on the table in front of me a nice fat looking letter from theeCOMMA Mother dearCOMMA but I'm afraidI wont have time to read it before I finish thisCOMMA as I am going sleighing in a few minutes & the postman may come before I get back. Thank thee for it though ever so much. And thank theeCOMMA dear ErnCOMMA for thy nice one which came the early part of the week. It was nice to hear from thee once again. If there are any loose pictures ofour house & Awbury floatinh around send those with the other photos.

Now good-by. With a great deal of love for each one of youCOMMA dear onesCOMMA I am
Your loving
Anna

PS. Please give my love to the girls & remember me to Simon if he is still with us.
